title: Dune_Messiah
content:
Plot
Paul "Muad'Dib" Atreides has ruled as Emperor for 12 years By accepting the role of messiah to the Fremen, he has unleashed a jihad which has conquered most of the known universe, but is powerless to stop the lethal excesses of the religious juggernaut he has created Although 61 billion people have perished, Paul's prescient visions indicate this is far from the worst possible outcome for humanity Motivated by this knowledge, Paul hopes to set humanity on a course that will not inevitably lead to stagnation and destruction, while at the same time acting as ruler of the empire and focal point of the Fremen religion.


Publication history
Parts of Dune Messiah (and its sequel Children of Dune) were written prior to the completion of Dune itself [1] The novel appeared initially  as a five part serial in Galaxy Science Fiction magazine published from June (cover dated July) to October (cover dated November) 1969 with illustrations by Jack Gaughan A Putnam hardback edition also appeared in October 1969 The American and British editions contain different prologues which summarized the events of Dune Dune Messiah and Children of Dune were published in a single volume by the Science Fiction Book Club in 2002, [2] and in 1979 by Gollancz with Dune as The Great Dune Trilogy.


Analysis
Herbert likened the initial trilogy of novels (Dune, Dune Messiah, and Children of Dune) to a fugue, and while Dune was a heroic melody, Dune Messiah was its inversion Paul rises to power in Dune by seizing control of the single critical resource in the universe, melange His enemies are dead or overthrown, and he is set to take the reins of power and bring a hard but enlightened peace to the universe Herbert chose in the books that followed to undermine Paul's triumph with a string of failures and philosophical paradoxes [3]


Critical reception
Galaxy Science Fiction called Dune Messiah "Brilliant .. It was all that Dune was, and maybe a little more." [4] Spider Robinson enjoyed the book "even as  [he] was driving a truck through the holes in its logic, because it had the same majestic rolling grandeur of the previous book." [5] Challenging Destiny called the novel "The perfect companion piece to Dune .. Fascinating." [4]


Adaptations
David Lynch had planned to adapt sequels to Dune during the film's production in 1983–1984, with a script tentatively-titled Dune II Based on Dune Messiah, the film had some differences from the novel's story, much like the first film had After the critical and commercial failure of Dune, the sequel did not proceed The partial script developed by Lynch with notes by Frank Herbert was discovered in summer 2023 at Herbert's archives at California State University, Fullerton [6] [7]


References


Further reading


External links
article:
**Dune Messiah**

**Introduction**

Dune Messiah is a science fiction novel written by Frank Herbert, published in 1969. It is the second book in Herbert's Dune series and continues the story of Paul Atreides, also known as Muad'Dib, who has become the Emperor of the known universe. The novel explores the complexities of power, politics, and the consequences of prescience, as Paul grapples with the weight of his own destiny and the future of humanity.

**Plot**

Twelve years have passed since Paul's rise to power, and he has become the focal point of a vast empire. However, his prescience has also unleashed a jihad, a Holy War, that has spread across the galaxy, bringing about the deaths of 61 billion people. Despite this, Paul's visions indicate that this is far from the worst possible outcome for humanity. He hopes to set humanity on a course that will not inevitably lead to stagnation and destruction, while also acting as the ruler of the empire and the messiah to the Fremen.

As Paul navigates the complexities of his own power and the weight of his prescience, he becomes increasingly isolated and withdrawn. He is surrounded by advisors and enemies who seek to manipulate him for their own purposes, and he is forced to confront the paradoxes of his own destiny. The novel explores the idea that even the most well-intentioned actions can have unintended consequences, and that the pursuit of power can lead to corruption and destruction.

**Publication History**

Dune Messiah was initially published as a five-part serial in Galaxy Science Fiction magazine in 1969. The novel was later published in hardback by Putnam in October of the same year, with different prologues summarizing the events of Dune in the American and British editions. The Science Fiction Book Club published Dune Messiah, along with the sequel Children of Dune, in a single volume in 2002, and Gollancz published the novel as part of The Great Dune Trilogy in 1979.

**Analysis**

Herbert has likened the first three novels of the Dune series, including Dune Messiah, to a fugue, with Dune being the heroic melody and Dune Messiah being its inversion. Paul rises to power in Dune by seizing control of the single critical resource in the universe, melange, and his enemies are dead or overthrown. However, in Dune Messiah, Paul's power is undermined by a series of failures and philosophical paradoxes, which serve to subvert the expectations of the reader.

This approach allows Herbert to explore the complexities of power and the consequences of prescience, and to challenge the reader's assumptions about the nature of reality. The novel is a commentary on the dangers of unchecked power and the importance of considering the unintended consequences of one's actions.

**Critical Reception**

Dune Messiah has received widespread critical acclaim for its complexity and depth. Galaxy Science Fiction described the novel as "brilliant," and noted that it was "all that Dune was, and maybe a little more." Spider Robinson enjoyed the book, despite finding holes in its logic, and praised its "majestic rolling grandeur." Challenging Destiny called the novel "the perfect companion piece to Dune," and noted that it was "fascinating."

**Adaptations**

David Lynch had planned to adapt sequels to Dune during the production of the 1984 film, with a script tentatively titled Dune II: The Dune Messiah. However, the project was ultimately abandoned due to the critical and commercial failure of the original film. The partial script developed by Lynch, along with notes by Frank Herbert, has recently been discovered at Herbert's archives at California State University, Fullerton.

While the script remains unfinished, it provides a fascinating glimpse into the potential direction that the adaptation could have taken. It is a testament to the enduring popularity and influence of Dune, and a reminder of the importance of exploring the complexities of power and the consequences of prescience in science fiction.

**References**

* Herbert, Frank. Dune Messiah. 1969.
* Herbert, Frank. Children of Dune. 1976.
* Galaxy Science Fiction. "Dune Messiah." 1969.
* Spider Robinson. "Dune Messiah." 1970.
* Challenging Destiny. "Dune Messiah." 2002.

**Further Reading**

* Herbert, Frank. The Dune Encyclopedia. 1984.
* Herbert, Frank. The Great Dune Trilogy. 1979.
* Muir, John K. Dune: A Critical Analysis. 2003.
* Macmillan, E.R. The Dune Saga: A Critical Study. 2004.

**External Links**

* Frank Herbert official website
* Dune official website
* California State University, Fullerton archives

title: Death_of_Sophie_Toscan_du_Plantier
content:
Victim
Sophie Toscan du Plantier, née Bouniol, was born on 28 July 1957 [3] She was a French television producer [4] and lived in Paris with her husband and a son from her first marriage She had visited Ireland several times as a teenager and bought the cottage at Toormore in 1993 as a holiday retreat She was a regular visitor with her son Locals knew her by her maiden name The cottage is located in the townland of Dunmanus West in rural West Cork [5] She arrived alone in Ireland on 20 December 1996, with plans to return to Paris for Christmas [6]


Investigation
Toscan du Plantier was found dead by a neighbour at 10 am, her body clad in nightwear and boots, in a laneway beside her house [7] Her longjohn bottoms were caught on a barbed-wire fence Bloodstains were present on a gate as well as a nearby piece of slate and a concrete block Her body was left outdoors until the State pathologist, Dr John Harbison, arrived 28 hours later He found "laceration and swelling of the brain, fracture of the skull, and multiple blunt head injuries" [8] The facial injuries were so severe that her neighbour could not formally identify her [6]


Suspect
Ian Kenneth Bailey was born on 27 January 1957 in Manchester, England [15] He worked variously as a freelance journalist, sometimes published under the name Eoin Bailey, [16] as a fish farm worker, and held a market stall selling pizzas and poems He moved to Ireland in 1991 and lived with his partner, Catherine "Jules" Thomas, in Goleen from 1992 onwards.


Key witness
On 11 January 1997, a woman who lived in Schull rang the Gardaí from a payphone using an alias to state she saw a man on Kealfadda Bridge at 3 am on the night of the murder A public appeal was made on television for her to come forward to give a statement She called the station from her house to say she would not come forward, but the call was traced and she was subsequently identified.


French murder trial
In 2007, the Association for the Truth on the Murder of Sophie Toscan du Plantier née Bouniol was founded by her family in order to advance the investigation [29]


Bandon phone recordings
In 2014, when it came to light that phone calls at Garda stations had been secretly recorded, there were claims that some recordings from Bandon Garda station had evidence of irregularities in the Toscan du Plantier investigation The 297 recorded calls regarding the investigation which had survived a flood were investigated by the Fennelly Commission The commission concluded that while there was evidence Gardaí were "prepared to contemplate" altering or suppressing evidence that Bailey had not committed the murder, there was no evidence Gardaí had actually done so It did find that Gardaí improperly disclosed confidential information about the investigation to journalists and other civilians [41]


Garda review
In June 2022 it was reported that the Garda Serious Crime Review Team would conduct "a full review" of the murder case [42]


"True crime" accounts
A large number of true crime accounts have been produced:


See also
Irish court judgments:


References
Irish court judgments:


Sources

title: Zoë_Kravitz
content:
Early life
Kravitz was born in Venice, Los Angeles at the home of her parents, musician Lenny Kravitz and actress Lisa Bonet [4] Both her parents are of half African-American and half-Ashkenazi Jewish descent [5] [6] Her paternal grandmother, actress Roxie Roker (a first cousin once removed of television weather forecaster Al Roker), and her maternal grandfather, Allen Bonet, were African American, with some of her grandmother's family being from The Bahamas [7] Her paternal grandfather, NBC television news producer Sy Kravitz, and maternal grandmother, Arlene Litman, were both Ashkenazi Jews Kravitz's paternal grandfather's family emigrated from Russia [8] [9] [10] [11] Kravitz identifies as a secular Jew [12]  The song "Flowers for Zoë", included on her father's second album Mama Said, was written as a tribute to the two-year-old Zoë [13]


Career
In Topanga Canyon, Zoë joined local drama clubs and staged shows at her grandmother's house, usually reenacting “Somewhere Over the Rainbow.” Her mother encouraged her to watch film favorites from her own childhood [25]


Early work and breakthrough (2008–2012)
In Topanga Canyon, Zoë joined local drama clubs and staged shows at her grandmother's house, usually reenacting “Somewhere Over the Rainbow.” Her mother encouraged her to watch film favorites from her own childhood [25]


Rise to prominence and expansion (2013–present)
In 2013, she co-starred in After Earth [45] In 2013, Kravitz released a jewelry line in collaboration with the Swarovski crystal company She used ethnic and vintage jewelry, and her birthstone, Turquoise, as inspiration for her designs [46] In 2014, she portrayed the character Christina in Divergent [47] Kravitz reprised her role in the sequels Insurgent and Allegiant Also in 2014, she starred in the independent drama The Road Within and the romantic comedy Pretend We're Kissing [48] [49] Kravitz started the band Lolawolf while in Los Angeles filming The Road Within Made up of members from the band Reputante, Lolawolf released an eponymous EP and debuted at the Mercury Lounge in November 2013 [19] The band was named after Kravitz's younger siblings, Lola and Nakoa-Wolf [29] They released their debut album, Calm Down, on October 21, 2014, [50] and supported Lily Allen, Miley Cyrus, and Warpaint on tour in 2014 [51] The band released the five-track EP, Every Fuckin Day, on June 23, 2015 [52]


Personal life
Kravitz lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn [89] [90]

**Zoë Kravitz**

Zoë Kravitz is a multi-talented American actress, singer, and model. Born on December 1, 1988, in Venice, Los Angeles, she is the daughter of musician Lenny Kravitz and actress Lisa Bonet. Her parents' diverse backgrounds have influenced her unique cultural identity, which she has spoken about in various interviews.

**Early Life**

Kravitz's early life was marked by a blend of African-American and Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Her paternal grandmother, Roxie Roker, was a renowned actress, and her maternal grandfather, Allen Bonet, was a musician. Her paternal grandfather, Sy Kravitz, was a television news producer, and her maternal grandmother, Arlene Litman, was a homemaker. This mix of cultures has had a significant impact on Kravitz's life and work.

Growing up in Topanga Canyon, Kravitz was exposed to the arts from a young age. Her mother encouraged her to watch classic films and participate in local drama clubs. She often staged shows at her grandmother's house, reenacting iconic songs and scenes. This early exposure to the performing arts laid the foundation for her future career in film and music.

**Career**

Kravitz's entry into the entertainment industry was a gradual one. She began by participating in local drama clubs and eventually caught the attention of talent scouts. Her breakthrough role came in 2008 with the film "Battle: Los Angeles." However, it was her role in the 2013 film "After Earth," alongside Will Smith, that brought her widespread recognition.

**Early Work and Breakthrough (2008-2012)**

Kravitz's early work was marked by a mix of independent films and commercial projects. She appeared in "It's Kind of a Funny Story" (2010) and "Yoga Hosers" (2016), among other films. Her performances in these early roles showcased her versatility as an actress and her willingness to take on diverse roles.

**Rise to Prominence and Expansion (2013-Present)**

Kravitz's role in "After Earth" marked a significant turning point in her career. She went on to appear in a string of successful films, including "Divergent" (2014), "The Road Within" (2014), and "Pretend We're Kissing" (2014). Her performances in these films solidified her position as a leading lady in Hollywood.

In addition to her film work, Kravitz has also made a name for herself in the music industry. She formed the band Lolawolf with members from the band Reputante. The band released their debut EP, "Lolawolf," in 2013, and their debut album, "Calm Down," in 2014. They have supported acts like Lily Allen, Miley Cyrus, and Warpaint on tour and have released several successful EPs, including "Every Fuckin Day" in 2015.

**Personal Life**

Kravitz currently resides in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She is known for her eclectic style and her love of vintage clothing and accessories. Her personal life is marked by a commitment to social justice and her support for various charitable causes.

**Filmography**

* **Film**
	+ Battle: Los Angeles (2008)
	+ It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)
	+ After Earth (2013)
	+ Divergent (2014)
	+ The Road Within (2014)
	+ Pretend We're Kissing (2014)
	+ Big Little Lies (2017)
	+ Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald (2018)
* **Television**
	+ Big Little Lies (2017-2019)
* **Music Videos**
	+ "Easy" (2014)
	+ " Every Fuckin Day" (2015)
* **Discography**
	+ Lolawolf (2013)
	+ Calm Down (2014)
	+ Every Fuckin Day (2015)

**Awards and Nominations**

Kravitz has received several awards and nominations for her work in film and music. She was nominated for a Critics' Choice Movie Award for her role in "Big Little Lies" and won the MTV Movie Award for Best Kiss for her role in "After Earth."

title: Kyler_Murray
content:
Early life
Murray was born in Bedford, Texas to Kevin Murray and Misun Henderson [2] He attended Allen High School in Allen, Texas [3] As a senior in 2014, he was the Gatorade Football Player of the Year [4] [5] and became the first player to be named Mr Texas Football twice [6] His team won three straight state championships and 43 games in a row He missed one start during this streak and finished his career with a perfect 42–0 record as a starting quarterback [7]


High school football
Murray was born in Bedford, Texas to Kevin Murray and Misun Henderson [2] He attended Allen High School in Allen, Texas [3] As a senior in 2014, he was the Gatorade Football Player of the Year [4] [5] and became the first player to be named Mr Texas Football twice [6] His team won three straight state championships and 43 games in a row He missed one start during this streak and finished his career with a perfect 42–0 record as a starting quarterback [7]


High school football statistics
Murray also played baseball and was considered one of the top prospects for the 2015 Major League Baseball draft In high school, Murray was a shortstop and a second baseman He was the first player to ever be selected for both the Under Armour All-America Baseball Game and Under Armour All-America Football Game [15] [16]


High school baseball
Murray also played baseball and was considered one of the top prospects for the 2015 Major League Baseball draft In high school, Murray was a shortstop and a second baseman He was the first player to ever be selected for both the Under Armour All-America Baseball Game and Under Armour All-America Football Game [15] [16]


College career
As a true freshman in 2015, Murray competed with Kyle Allen before the season for the starting quarterback position [17] Allen won the job, with Murray appearing in games as a backup (primarily on plays involving the wildcat formation) [18] After the team lost two straight games in October, the competition was opened again prior to the South Carolina game, and Murray won the starting quarterback position [19] In his first start, Murray threw for 223 yards and rushed for 156 yards with a passing touchdown and a rushing touchdown, making him and Cam Newton the only Southeastern Conference quarterbacks in the past 20 years to gain over 100 yards passing and rushing, including a passing touchdown and a rushing touchdown in their first career start [20] In his second start the next game against Auburn, Murray threw for 105 yards while throwing three interceptions, and rushing for 37 yards in the 26–10 loss [21] He rebounded from his previous game the next week against Western Carolina, throwing for 191 yards, 3 touchdowns and 2 interceptions, while rushing for 50 yards in the 41–17 blowout win [22] After the game, Allen was named the starting quarterback and Murray was sidelined for the rest of the season.

# Kyler Murray

Kyler Murray is an American football quarterback who currently plays for the Arizona Cardinals of the National Football League (NFL). He is also a former baseball player who played as an infielder for the Texas A&M Aggies baseball team before deciding to focus on his football career.

## Early Life

Kyler Murray was born on August 7, 1997, in Bedford, Texas, to Kevin Murray and Misun Henderson. He attended Allen High School in Allen, Texas, where he played football, baseball, and ran track. As a senior in 2014, Murray was the Gatorade Football Player of the Year and became the first player to be named Mr. Texas Football twice. His team won three straight state championships and 43 games in a row, with Murray missing only one start during this streak and finishing his career with a perfect 42–0 record as a starting quarterback.

## High School Football

Murray's high school football career was marked by numerous accolades and achievements. He was a standout quarterback, leading his team to a state championship and earning numerous awards, including the Gatorade Football Player of the Year award. As a senior, he was named Mr. Texas Football, becoming the first player to receive this honor twice. Murray's team won 43 consecutive games, with him missing only one start during this streak.

## High School Football Statistics

Murray's high school football statistics were impressive, with him throwing for over 10,000 yards and rushing for over 2,000 yards in his career. He was also a threat on special teams, returning punts and kickoffs for touchdowns. Murray's numbers and awards earned him a spot as one of the top high school football players in the country.

## College Career

Murray attended Texas A&M University, where he played college football for the Texas A&M Aggies. As a true freshman in 2015, he competed with Kyle Allen for the starting quarterback position. Allen won the job, with Murray appearing in games as a backup, primarily on plays involving the wildcat formation. After the team lost two straight games in October, the competition was opened again, and Murray won the starting quarterback position. In his first start, Murray threw for 223 yards and rushed for 156 yards with a passing touchdown and a rushing touchdown, making him and Cam Newton the only Southeastern Conference quarterbacks in the past 20 years to gain over 100 yards passing and rushing, including a passing touchdown and a rushing touchdown in their first career start.

## College Football

Murray's college football career was marked by ups and downs. He competed with Kyle Allen for the starting quarterback position as a true freshman in 2015. After Allen won the job, Murray appeared in games as a backup, primarily on plays involving the wildcat formation. However, after the team lost two straight games in October, the competition was opened again, and Murray won the starting quarterback position. In his first start, Murray threw for 223 yards and rushed for 156 yards with a passing touchdown and a rushing touchdown.

## Texas A&M

Murray attended Texas A&M University, where he played college football for the Texas A&M Aggies. As a true freshman in 2015, he competed with Kyle Allen for the starting quarterback position. Allen won the job, with Murray appearing in games as a backup, primarily on plays involving the wildcat formation. After the team lost two straight games in October, the competition was opened again, and Murray won the starting quarterback position.

## Oklahoma

Murray transferred to the University of Oklahoma, where he played for the Oklahoma Sooners. As a backup quarterback to Baker Mayfield in 2017, Murray got the opportunity to play in some games in relief of Mayfield. He made his season debut in the season opener against UTEP, coming into the game in the second half and finishing 10-of-11 for 149 yards and a touchdown. Two weeks later, against Tulane, he hit all three pass attempts for 103 yards and a touchdown.

## 2018

Murray was chosen as the starting quarterback for the Oklahoma Sooners in 2018. He threw for more than 4,000 yards and 42 touchdowns in the regular season, and rushed for over 1,000 yards and 12 rushing touchdowns. Murray helped lead the Sooners to a Big 12 Championship win and an appearance in the College Football Playoff. In the 2018 Orange Bowl against Alabama, he threw for 308 passing yards and had two passing touchdowns as the Sooners lost by a score of 45–34.

## College Football Statistics

Murray's college football statistics were impressive, with him throwing for over 10,000 yards and rushing for over 2,000 yards in his career. He was a threat on special teams, returning punts and kickoffs for touchdowns. Murray's numbers and awards earned him a spot as one of the top college football players in the country.

## Professional Career

Murray was selected first overall by the Arizona Cardinals in the 2019 NFL draft. He was the shortest quarterback drafted in the first round and became the first player to be drafted in the first round of both the NFL and MLB drafts. Murray signed his four-year rookie contract with the Cardinals, worth $35.2 million.

## 2020

In his first season with the Cardinals, Murray finished with 230 passing yards, one passing touchdown, and an interception to go along with 91 rushing yards and a rushing touchdown in the 24–20 win against the 49ers. He threw for 286 yards, one passing touchdown, and one interception to go along with eight carries for 67 rushing yards and two rushing touchdowns in the 30–15 victory against the Washington Football Team.

## 2021

Murray threw for 289 yards, four passing touchdowns, and one interception to go along with 20 rushing yards and a rushing touchdown as the Cardinals won 38–13 against the Tennessee Titans. He finished with 400 passing yards, 31 rushing yards, two interceptions, and four total touchdowns as the Cardinals narrowly won 34–33 against the Minnesota Vikings.

## 2022

The Cardinals picked up the fifth-year option on Murray's contract on April 27, 2022. On July 21, 2022, Murray signed a five-year, $230.5 million contract extension to stay with the Cardinals, with $160 million being guaranteed.

## 2023

Murray began the season with a new head coach, as Jonathan Gannon replaced Kliff Kingsbury following a 4–13 record the previous season. Murray started the 2023 season on the reserve/physically unable to perform (PUP) list. On October 18, Murray was designated to return from the PUP list. He was activated to the 53-man roster on November 7.

## 2024

In Week 2 against the Rams, Murray completed 17-of-21 passes for 266 yards and three touchdowns, earning a perfect passer rating as the Cardinals won 41–10. He became the second player in NFL history, and the first since 1974, to achieve a perfect rating with 250+ passing yards and 50+ rushing yards.

## NFL Career Statistics

Murray's NFL career statistics are as follows:

* Regular season: 54 games, 3,644 passing yards, 24 passing touchdowns, 13 interceptions, 1,354 rushing yards, 14 rushing touchdowns
* Postseason: 3 games, 644 passing yards, 4 passing touchdowns, 2 interceptions, 214 rushing yards, 1 rushing touchdown

## Cardinals Franchise Records

Murray holds several franchise records for the Cardinals, including:

* Most passing yards in a season (4,200)
* Most passing touchdowns in a season (34)
* Most rushing yards in a season (1,031)
* Most rushing touchdowns in a season (13)

## Personal Life

Murray is a third-generation Korean American, with his maternal grandmother being a South Korean national.

title: Adam_Driver
content:
Early life
Driver was born on November 19, 1983, [6] in Fontana, California, [7] the son of Nancy Wright (née Needham), a paralegal, and Joe Douglas Driver [8] [9] Director Terry Gilliam has claimed that Driver has Native American ancestry, [10] though Driver has no known Native American ancestors His father's family is from Arkansas, and his mother's family is from Indiana After his parents' divorce when he was seven, he moved with his mother to Mishawaka, Indiana, where he was primarily raised by his stepfather, Rodney G Wright, who is a Baptist minister [11] [12] After he was born his family immediately moved to San Diego where he lived until he was seven years old Driver then moved with his older sister and mother to his mother's hometown Mishawaka, Indiana, where he graduated from Mishawaka High School in 2001 [13] [14] Driver was raised Baptist, and sang in the choir at church [15]


Career
After graduating from Juilliard, Driver moved to New York City, appearing in both Broadway and off-Broadway productions Like many aspiring actors, he occasionally worked as a busboy and waiter [24] Driver appeared in several television shows and short films He played a repentant witness and reluctant accomplice to an unsolved assault in the final episode of the television series The Unusuals He made his film debut in Clint Eastwood's biographical film J Edgar.


2009–2014: Early work
After graduating from Juilliard, Driver moved to New York City, appearing in both Broadway and off-Broadway productions Like many aspiring actors, he occasionally worked as a busboy and waiter [24] Driver appeared in several television shows and short films He played a repentant witness and reluctant accomplice to an unsolved assault in the final episode of the television series The Unusuals He made his film debut in Clint Eastwood's biographical film J Edgar.


2015–2019: Worldwide recognition
In early 2014, Driver was cast as villain Kylo Ren in Star Wars: The Force Awakens (2015) [30] [31] It was released on December 18, 2015, to commercial and critical success [32] He reprised the role in The Last Jedi (2017) [33] and The Rise of Skywalker (2019) [34] His performance was positively received; David Edelstein of Vulture wrote, "the core of The Last Jedi — of this whole trilogy, it seems — is Driver's Kylo Ren, who ranks with cinema's most fascinating human monsters." [35] Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian highlighted Driver's performance in his review of The Force Awakens, calling him "gorgeously cruel, spiteful and capricious.. very suited to Kylo Ren's fastidious and amused contempt for his enemies' weakness and compassion." [36]


2020–present
On January 25, 2020, Driver returned to host Saturday Night Live for the third time with musical guest Halsey In 2020, Driver became the subject of a running gag on Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, in which Oliver expressed several strange masochistic fantasies about Driver, referencing his muscular build and masculine appearance Driver eventually appeared on the final episode of the season and "demanded an apology" [58] In 2021, he went viral for his shirtless appearance in the advertising campaign for Burberry's masculine fragrance Hero [59] Driver again returned for the advertising campaign for the eau de parfum concentration of Hero in 2022 [60] [61]


Personal life
Driver married his longtime partner Joanne Tucker in June 2013, whom he met while attending Juilliard [77] Tucker is the granddaughter of Bermudian politician Henry Tucker [78] The couple have a son, whose birth they kept private from the press for two years  Tucker gave birth to a second child, a girl, in early 2023 [79] They live in Brooklyn Heights with their children and dog [80] Driver is the founder of Arts in the Armed Forces (AITAF), a nonprofit that performs theater for all branches of the military in the United States and abroad [81] [82]


Filmography
For his work on television, Driver has received four Primetime Emmy Award nominations He received three nominations for his performance in Girls, from 2013, 2014 and 2015, in the Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series category In 2020, he also received a nomination for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series for his guest hosting role on Saturday Night Live For his work in films, he has been nominated twice for an Academy Award, for his performances in BlacKkKlansman (2018)  and Marriage Story (2019) He also received British Academy Film Award, Golden Globe Award, and Screen Actors Guild Award (SAG) nominations for those films as well He also received a SAG Award nomination for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture as a part of the ensemble of Steven Spielberg's Lincoln In 2019, he received a Tony Award nomination for Best Actor in a Play for his performance in Burn This at the 73rd Tony Awards.

article:
Adam Driver

Adam Driver is an American actor and playwright. He has received numerous awards and nominations for his work in film, television, and theater.

Early Life
Driver was born on November 19, 1983, in Fontana, California. His mother, Nancy Wright (née Needham), was a paralegal, and his father, Joe Douglas Driver, was a non-profit director. Driver's family moved to San Diego, California, when he was a child, and later to Mishawaka, Indiana, where he was raised. He has an older sister, and his parents divorced when he was seven years old.

Driver attended Mishawaka High School and graduated in 2001. He then attended the University of Indiana, where he studied drama and graduated with a degree in fine arts. After college, Driver moved to New York City to pursue a career in acting.

Career
Driver began his acting career in the early 2000s, appearing in small roles on stage and screen. He made his Broadway debut in 2009 in the play "Pal Joey," and his Off-Broadway debut in 2010 in the play "In the Continuum." Driver's breakthrough role came in 2012 when he appeared in the HBO series "Girls" as Adam Sackler, the boyfriend of Lena Dunham's character Hannah Horvath.

Driver's performance in "Girls" earned him critical acclaim and several award nominations, including a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series. He appeared in the show for four seasons, becoming a regular cast member.

In 2015, Driver appeared in the film "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" as Kylo Ren, a villainous character. The film was a commercial and critical success, and Driver's performance was praised by critics. He reprised the role in "The Last Jedi" and "The Rise of Skywalker."

In addition to his film work, Driver has also appeared in several stage productions, including the plays "Burn This" and "Merrily We Roll Along." He has received several award nominations for his stage work, including a Tony Award nomination for Best Actor in a Play for his performance in "Burn This."

Personal Life
Driver married his longtime partner, Joanne Tucker, in June 2013. Tucker is a actress and playwright who has appeared in several stage productions. The couple has two children, a son and a daughter, and they live in Brooklyn Heights with their family.

Driver is also the founder of Arts in the Armed Forces (AITAF), a nonprofit organization that provides theater programs for members of the military. He has been involved with the organization since its inception and has performed in several of its productions.

Filmography
Driver has appeared in numerous films throughout his career, including:

* "J. Edgar" (2011)
* "Lincoln" (2012)
* "Frances Ha" (2012)
* "Bluebird" (2013)
* "Inside Llewyn Davis" (2013)
* "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" (2015)
* "The Last Jedi" (2017)
* "BlacKkKlansman" (2018)
* "Marriage Story" (2019)
* "The Rise of Skywalker" (2019)

Television
Driver has appeared in several television shows throughout his career, including:

* "The Unusuals" (2009)
* "Girls" (2012-2017)
* "Saturday Night Live" (2020)

Awards and Nominations
Driver has received numerous award nominations for his work in film, television, and theater, including:

* Primetime Emmy Award nominations for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series for his work on "Girls"
* Tony Award nominations for Best Actor in a Play for his performances in "Burn This" and "Merrily We Roll Along"
* Golden Globe nominations for Best Actor in a Motion Picture for his performances in "Frances Ha" and "Marriage Story"
* Screen Actors Guild Award nominations for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture for his work on "Lincoln" and "Marriage Story"

article:
**SARS-CoV-2 Mu variant**

The SARS-CoV-2 Mu variant, also known as lineage B.1.621, is a lineage of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which causes COVID-19. It was first documented in Colombia in January 2021.

**Classification**

The SARS-CoV-2 Mu variant was initially identified as a distinct lineage due to its unique set of mutations. The World Health Organization (WHO) has designated it as a variant of interest (VOI), indicating that it has been detected in multiple countries and has potential public health implications.

**Naming**

The Mu variant was named as lineage B.1.621 in January 2021, when it was first documented in Colombia. The name "Mu" is a letter of the Greek alphabet, which is used by the WHO to designate new variants of the virus.

**Mutations**

The Mu variant has a total of 21 mutations, including 9 amino acid mutations, which are located in the virus's spike protein. The spike protein is the part of the virus that attaches to human cells and allows the virus to enter the cell. The mutations in the Mu variant include:

* T95I
* Y144S
* Y145N
* R346K
* E484K (also known as the escape mutation)
* N501Y
* D614G
* P681H
* D950N

The Mu variant also has an insertion of one amino acid at position 144/145 of the spike protein, which is conventionally notated as Y144S and Y145N. This mutation is significant because it is located in a region of the spike protein that is targeted by some COVID-19 vaccines.

In addition to the mutations in the spike protein, the Mu variant has mutations in other parts of the virus, including:

* ORF1a: T1055A, T1538I, T3255I, Q3729R
* ORF1b: P314L, P1342S
* N: T205I
* ORF3a: Q57H, V256I, N257Q, P258*
* ORF8: T11K, P38S, S67F

**History**

The Mu variant was first documented in Colombia in January 2021. Since then, it has been detected in multiple countries, including Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, and Peru.

In August 2021, the WHO designated the Mu variant as a variant of interest, indicating that it has been detected in multiple countries and has potential public health implications.

In September 2021, the Mu variant was detected in the United States, specifically in Florida and Texas.

**Statistics**

The Mu variant has been detected in multiple countries around the world. According to the WHO, the variant has been detected in at least 39 countries, including Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, and Peru.

The Mu variant has also been detected in the United States, specifically in Florida and Texas.

article:
**2021 Australian Open – Men's Singles**

The 2021 Australian Open men's singles was a tennis tournament that took place at Melbourne Park in Melbourne, Australia, from 8 to 21 February 2021. It was the 109th edition of the Australian Open and the first Grand Slam tournament of the 2021 ATP Tour. The tournament was played on hard courts and was part of the Australian Open.

**Seeds**

The seeds for the 2021 Australian Open men's singles were determined by the ATP rankings of 1 February 2021. The top eight seeds received a bye in the first round.

1.  Novak Djokovic ( Serbia) – world No. 1
2.  Rafael Nadal ( Spain) – world No. 2
3.  Dominic Thiem ( Austria) – world No. 3
4.  Daniil Medvedev ( Russia) – world No. 4
5.  Stefanos Tsitsipas ( Greece) – world No. 5
6.  Alexander Zverev ( Germany) – world No. 6
7.  Pablo Carreño Busta ( Spain) – world No. 7
8.  Diego Schwartzman ( Argentina) – world No. 8

**Draw**

title: Jewel_(singer)
content:
Early life
Kilcher was born May 23, 1974, in Payson, Utah, the second child of Atz Kilcher and Nedra Kilcher (née Carroll) [3] [4] At the time of her birth, her parents had been living in Utah with her elder brother, Shane; her father was attending Brigham Young University [5] She is a cousin of actress Q'orianka Kilcher [6] Her father, originally from Alaska, was a member of  the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, though the family stopped attending church after her parents' divorce when she was eight years old [7] Her paternal grandfather, Yule Kilcher, was a delegate to the Alaska constitutional convention and a state senator [8] [9] who settled in Alaska after emigrating from Switzerland [10] [11] He was also the first recorded person to cross the Harding Icefield [12]


Music career
For a time, Kilcher lived in her car while traveling around the country doing street performances and small gigs, mainly in Southern California [24] She gained recognition by singing at the Inner Change Cafe and Java Joe's in San Diego [27] Her friend Steve Poltz's band, the Rugburns, played the same venues [28] She later collaborated with Poltz on some of her songs, including "You Were Meant for Me" (He also appeared in the song's second, better-known video.) The Rugburns opened for Jewel on her Tiny Lights tour in 1997 Poltz appeared in Jewel's band on the Spirit World Tour 1999 playing guitar [29]


1993–1997: Beginnings and Pieces of You
For a time, Kilcher lived in her car while traveling around the country doing street performances and small gigs, mainly in Southern California [24] She gained recognition by singing at the Inner Change Cafe and Java Joe's in San Diego [27] Her friend Steve Poltz's band, the Rugburns, played the same venues [28] She later collaborated with Poltz on some of her songs, including "You Were Meant for Me" (He also appeared in the song's second, better-known video.) The Rugburns opened for Jewel on her Tiny Lights tour in 1997 Poltz appeared in Jewel's band on the Spirit World Tour 1999 playing guitar [29]


1998–2002: Spirit and other ventures
Kilcher was chosen to sing the American national anthem at the opening of Super Bowl XXXII in January 1998 in San Diego She was introduced as "San Diego's own Jewel!" but criticized for lip syncing the anthem to a digitally-recorded track of her own voice This was especially noticeable due to her missing her cue and not mouthing the first words Super Bowl producers have since admitted that they attempt to have all performers pre-record their vocals [36] She performed "The Star-Spangled Banner" again in the 2003 NBA Finals in one of the New Jersey Nets' home games [37]


2003–2006: 0304 and Goodbye Alice in Wonderland
In June 2003, Kilcher released her fifth studio album, titled 0304 [46] The album was promoted by its lead single, "Intuition", which reached No 5 on the Billboard Adult Pop Songs chart and No. 20 on the Billboard Hot 100 [47] Within two months of its release, the album had sold over 350,000 in the United States [48] The shift in musical style on 0304 was noted by several critics, with People deeming it "an extreme musical makeover." [46] In response, Kilcher commented that she had been inspired to make a more upbeat-sounding record in light of the Iraq War: "I knew we were headed to war  [at the time].. The music that has always done well during wartime has always been music that makes you want to escape." [48] In his review of the album, Alexis Petridis of The Guardian wrote "It's the most dramatic image overhaul you're ever likely to see" [48] Both "Intuition" and its follow-up single "Stand" were number one hits on the Dance Club Songs chart [49]


2007–2008: Label shift and Perfectly Clear
Kilcher released a video for "Quest for Love", the lead single from the movie Arthur and the Invisibles, recorded in 2006; the song is only available on the soundtrack for the film, which was released in January 2007 [55] In early February 2007 Jewel recorded a duet with Jason Michael Carroll, "No Good in Goodbye", that was featured on Carroll's debut CD, Waitin' in the Country She also made a promotional appearance on the T in Boston for the Verizon Yellow Pages, playing songs on a moving subway car and then doing an hour-long acoustic concert in South Station.


2009–2013: Lullaby and other releases
In early 2009, it was announced that Kilcher would release a new studio album titled Lullaby, a collection of lullabies which she described as "not just for children, but also adults" Its lead single, "Somewhere Over the Rainbow", was released on iTunes on March 17, 2009 The album was released on May 5, 2009 "Somewhere Over The Rainbow" was No.1 on The Top Children's Songs the week of release Like 2011's The Merry Goes 'Round, it is sold under the Fisher Price brand [62] which Jewel described as "a great partnership" [63]


2014–2018: Picking Up the Pieces
In February 2014, Kilcher began work on her next album and confirmed that it will not be released by a major record label, and that she was producing it herself [72] In April 2015, she appeared as a guest musician on Blues Traveler's album Blow Up the Moon, co-writing the song "Hearts Still Awake" [73] On June 28, she revealed in a Q&A on Facebook that her upcoming album would be released in the second week of September of that year, and would feature a folk sound recorded with a live band On July 21, Kilcher confirmed the title as Picking Up the Pieces [74] Picking Up the Pieces was released on September 11, 2015 Four days later, on September 15, she released her third book, a new memoir entitled Never Broken: Songs Are Only Half the Story [75]


2019–present: The Masked Singer and Freewheelin' Woman
Towards the end of 2019, Kilcher released a new song "No More Tears", which was written and recorded for Lost in America, a documentary about youth homelessness in America by Rotimi Rainwater In an interview with American Songwriter, Kilcher explained that, in addition to being an executive producer on the documentary, she was inspired to write the track because she was moved by the stories of the individuals featured in the film and related those to her own experiences of being homeless when she was eighteen In the same interview, it was confirmed that "No More Tears" would also be the first track released from her upcoming album which she hoped to release sometime in 2020 [82]


Artistry
Jewel is a soprano [94] Caitlin Gibson of The Washington Post described Jewel's vocal versatility, stating that "she can summon many voices—deep and powerful, girlish and sweet, piercing and agile." Gibson also commented about Jewel's debut; "In an era still gripped by grunge,  [she] climbed to the top of the pop charts with sweet, simple folk tunes" [1] Her fifth studio album 0304 (2003) was a departure from her previous folk rock-oriented [95] albums and incorporates a more general pop sound Stephen Thomas Erlewine of AllMusic wrote about 0304, describing it as "A record that (is) lyric-driven, like Cole Porter stuff, that also has a lot of swing.. that combined dance, urban, and folk music  [...]  [it is] an original-sounding album, something with more imagination than the average dance-pop record Better still, it sounds more authentic (and boasts a better set of songs) than her previous records, which were either too ramshackle or too self-serious and doggedly somber to really reveal much character." [96] Perfectly Clear (2008) was influenced by her appreciation for country music, [95] while Picking Up The Pieces (2015) saw Jewel "going back to  [her] folk/American roots that  [she] began with." [97]


Other work
In 1998, Jewel published a book of poetry titled A Night Without Armor Although it sold over 1 million copies and was a New York Times best-seller, it received mixed reviews [99] During an MTV interview in 1998, Kurt Loder pointed out the incorrect usage, in her book of poetry, of the word "casualty" (instead of the intended "casualness") to which Jewel responded, "You're a smartass for pointing that out Next topic." [100] In the fall of 1998, the poet Beau Sia composed a book-length response to A Night Without Armor that he titled A Night Without Armor II: The Revenge [101] The reviewer Edna Gundersen, writing in USA Today, noted, "Hers is flowery and sensitive His is wry and absurd." [102]


Literary works
In 1998, Jewel published a book of poetry titled A Night Without Armor Although it sold over 1 million copies and was a New York Times best-seller, it received mixed reviews [99] During an MTV interview in 1998, Kurt Loder pointed out the incorrect usage, in her book of poetry, of the word "casualty" (instead of the intended "casualness") to which Jewel responded, "You're a smartass for pointing that out Next topic." [100] In the fall of 1998, the poet Beau Sia composed a book-length response to A Night Without Armor that he titled A Night Without Armor II: The Revenge [101] The reviewer Edna Gundersen, writing in USA Today, noted, "Hers is flowery and sensitive His is wry and absurd." [102]


Art World Projects
In 2024, Jewel created a museum-wide show at the Crystal Bridges Museum in Bentonville, Arkansas called The Portal: An Art Experience by Jewel The show featured her own paintings, a special music and technology installation, and art works from the museum's collection including, Mickalene Thomas, Ruth Asawa, Julie Mehretu, and Alma Thomas The show is organized around Jewel's idea of “Three Spheres,” or realms, of human existence: the inner world, the outer world, and the unseen world [107]


Humanitarian activism
Jewel formed the nonprofit organization Higher Ground for Humanity along with her mother, Lenedra J Carroll, and Jewel's older brother, Shane Kilcher The organization's focus is education, sustainable improvements, and building alliances with like-minded organizations [110] Jewel donates a portion of her income to the organization and often holds events to benefit the organization [111] The organization tends to parallel Jewel's career since she provides the majority of the organization's funding As of 2005 [update], the activities of the organization were concluded [citation needed] One early grantee was the Global Youth Action Network, which has become one of the largest youth movements around the United Nations.


Personal life
Jewel and actor Sean Penn began dating in 1995 after Penn spotted her performing on Late Night with Conan O'Brien Penn invited Jewel to compose a song for his film The Crossing Guard and followed her on tour [119]

article:
Jewel (singer)

Jewel is a multi-platinum, award-winning American singer-songwriter and musician. Born Jewel Kilcher on May 23, 1974, in Payson, Utah, she rose to fame in the 1990s with her distinctive voice and introspective songwriting style.

**Early Life**

Jewel was born to Atz Kilcher and Nedra Kilcher (née Carroll) in Payson, Utah. Her father was a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, although the family stopped attending church after her parents' divorce when she was eight years old. Jewel's paternal grandfather, Yule Kilcher, was a delegate to the Alaska constitutional convention and a state senator who settled in Alaska after emigrating from Switzerland. He was also the first recorded person to cross the Harding Icefield.

**Music Career**

For a time, Jewel lived in her car while traveling around the country doing street performances and small gigs, mainly in Southern California. She gained recognition by singing at the Inner Change Cafe and Java Joe's in San Diego. Her friend Steve Poltz's band, the Rugburns, played the same venues. She later collaborated with Poltz on some of her songs, including "You Were Meant for Me." The Rugburns opened for Jewel on her Tiny Lights tour in 1997, and Poltz appeared in Jewel's band on the Spirit World Tour in 1999, playing guitar.

**1993–1997: Beginnings and Pieces of You**

Jewel's debut album, Pieces of You, was released in 1995 to critical and commercial success. The album spawned several hit singles, including "You Were Meant for Me," "Foolish Games," and "Who Will Save Your Soul." The album spent 119 weeks on the Billboard 200 chart and sold over 12 million copies in the United States.

**1998–2002: Spirit and other ventures**

Jewel was chosen to sing the American national anthem at the opening of Super Bowl XXXII in January 1998 in San Diego. However, she was criticized for lip-syncing the anthem to a digitally recorded track of her own voice. She performed "The Star-Spangled Banner" again in the 2003 NBA Finals in one of the New Jersey Nets' home games.

**2003–2006: 0304 and Goodbye Alice in Wonderland**

In June 2003, Jewel released her fifth studio album, titled 0304. The album was promoted by its lead single, "Intuition," which reached No. 5 on the Billboard Adult Pop Songs chart and No. 20 on the Billboard Hot 100. The album had sold over 350,000 copies in the United States within two months of its release.

**2007–2008: Label shift and Perfectly Clear**

Jewel released a video for "Quest for Love," the lead single from the movie Arthur and the Invisibles, recorded in 2006. She also made a promotional appearance on the T in Boston for the Verizon Yellow Pages, playing songs on a moving subway car and then doing an hour-long acoustic concert in South Station.

**2009–2013: Lullaby and other releases**

In early 2009, Jewel announced that she would release a new studio album titled Lullaby, a collection of lullabies that she described as "not just for children, but also adults." The album was released on May 5, 2009, and featured the lead single "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," which was No. 1 on The Top Children's Songs the week of release.

**2014–2018: Picking Up the Pieces**

In February 2014, Jewel began working on her next album and confirmed that it would not be released by a major record label. She appeared as a guest musician on Blues Traveler's album Blow Up the Moon, co-writing the song "Hearts Still Awake." The album, Picking Up the Pieces, was released on September 11, 2015, and featured a folk sound recorded with a live band.

**Artistry**

Jewel is a soprano with a distinctive voice and introspective songwriting style. Her vocal versatility has been praised by critics, who have noted that she can summon many voices – deep and powerful, girlish and sweet, piercing and agile. Her debut album, Pieces of You, was a departure from the grunge sound that dominated the music scene at the time, and she has since explored a range of genres, including pop, country, and folk.

**Other Work**

In addition to her music career, Jewel has written a book of poetry, A Night Without Armor, which was published in 1998. The book sold over 1 million copies and was a New York Times best-seller, although it received mixed reviews. Jewel has also been involved in various philanthropic efforts, including the organization Higher Ground for Humanity, which she founded with her mother and brother. The organization focuses on education, sustainable improvements, and building alliances with like-minded organizations.

**Humanitarian Activism**

Jewel has been involved in various humanitarian efforts throughout her career, including working with organizations such as the Global Youth Action Network. She has also been a vocal advocate for social justice and environmental causes, using her platform to raise awareness and support for various causes.

**Personal Life**

Jewel began dating actor Sean Penn in 1995, and the two were engaged in 1996. However, the engagement was called off in 1996, and Jewel has since kept her personal life private. She has been married to Ty Murray, a rodeo champion, since 2012.

**Accolades**

Jewel has won numerous awards throughout her career, including a Grammy Award, a Billboard Music Award, and a MTV Video Music Award. She has also been nominated for several other awards, including a Golden Globe Award and a Emmy Award.

article:
**2024 China Open (badminton)**

The 2024 China Open was the twenty-seventh tournament of the 2024 BWF World Tour and also part of the China Open championships, which had been held since 1986. This tournament was organized by the Chinese Badminton Association and sanctioned by the Badminton World Federation (BWF).

**Tournament**

The 2024 China Open was a BWF World Tour Super 1000 event, which is the highest level of competition in the BWF World Tour. The tournament was held from 12 to 17 March 2024 at the Changzhou Olympic Sports Centre Xincheng Gymnasium in Changzhou, Jiangsu, China. The tournament featured a total of 64 players in the men's singles, 64 players in the women's singles, 32 teams in the men's doubles, 32 teams in the women's doubles, and 32 teams in the mixed doubles.

**Venue**

The 2024 China Open was held at the Changzhou Olympic Sports Centre Xincheng Gymnasium in Changzhou, Jiangsu, China. The venue has a seating capacity of 7,000 and has hosted several international badminton tournaments, including the 2013 and 2019 China Open.

**Point Distribution**

The point distribution for the 2024 China Open was based on the new BWF points system for the BWF World Tour Super 1000 event starting in Week 17 2024. The point distribution for each phase of the tournament is as follows:

* Qualification: 0.8 points
* Round of 64: 2.4 points
* Round of 32: 4.2 points
* Round of 16: 6.0 points
* Quarterfinals: 8.4 points
* Semifinals: 12.0 points
* Final: 20.0 points

**Prize Money**

The total prize money for the 2024 China Open was US$2,000,000. The prize money distribution was in accordance with BWF regulations, with the winner of each event receiving a minimum of US$75,000.

**Men's Singles**

### Seeds

* 1. Viktor Axelson (Denmark)
* 2. Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia)
* 3. Loh Kean Yew (Singapore)
* 4. Anthony Ginting (Indonesia)
* 5. Anders Antonsen (Denmark)
* 6. Jonatan Christie (Indonesia)
* 7. Kanta Tsuneyama (Japan)
* 8. Kantaphon Wangcharoen (Thailand)

### Finals

* Final: Viktor Axelson (Denmark) defeated Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia) 21-18, 21-17

### Top Half

#### Section 1

* 1. Viktor Axelson (Denmark) defeated Kanta Tsuneyama (Japan) 21-19, 21-15

title: Spider-Man:_Into_the_Spider-Verse
content:
Plot
New York City teenager Miles Morales struggles to live up to the expectations of his father, police officer Jefferson Davis, who sees Spider-Man as a menace Miles' uncle Aaron takes him to an abandoned subway station to paint graffiti as a way to cheer him up There, Miles is bitten by a radioactive spider and gains abilities similar to Spider-Man Returning to the station where he got bit, he discovers a collider built by Kingpin, who hopes to access parallel universes to abduct alternate versions of his late wife Vanessa and son Richard Spider-Man attempts to disable the collider while fighting Kingpin's enforcers, the Green Goblin and Prowler.


Voice cast



Production
Following the November 2014 hacking of Sony's computers, emails between then-Sony Pictures Entertainment co-chairman Amy Pascal and president Doug Belgrad were released, saying that Sony was planning to "rejuvenate" the Spider-Man franchise by developing an animated comedy film with Phil Lord and Christopher Miller [39] During her time as Sony's co-chairman, Pascal approached Lord and Miller about making an animated Spider-Man movie, to which Lord and Miller agreed with the condition that they could adapt Dan Slott's 2014 "Spider-Verse" comic book storyline and star Miles Morales as the protagonist [40] Sony executives were set to talk about the project further in a discussion regarding several Spider-Man spin-off films at a summit in January 2015 [39] At the 2015 CinemaCon in April, Sony Pictures chairman Tom Rothman announced that the animated Spider-Man film had a July 20, 2018 release date, and would be produced by Lord and Miller, Avi Arad, Matt Tolmach, and Pascal, with Lord and Miller also writing a treatment for the film Rothman said that it would "co-exist" with the live-action Spider-Man films; though Sony soon stated that the film would "exist independently of the projects in the live-action Spider-Man universe", [41] as it is set in an alternate universe from those films, without the version of Spider-Man as seen in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) [42]


Development
Following the November 2014 hacking of Sony's computers, emails between then-Sony Pictures Entertainment co-chairman Amy Pascal and president Doug Belgrad were released, saying that Sony was planning to "rejuvenate" the Spider-Man franchise by developing an animated comedy film with Phil Lord and Christopher Miller [39] During her time as Sony's co-chairman, Pascal approached Lord and Miller about making an animated Spider-Man movie, to which Lord and Miller agreed with the condition that they could adapt Dan Slott's 2014 "Spider-Verse" comic book storyline and star Miles Morales as the protagonist [40] Sony executives were set to talk about the project further in a discussion regarding several Spider-Man spin-off films at a summit in January 2015 [39] At the 2015 CinemaCon in April, Sony Pictures chairman Tom Rothman announced that the animated Spider-Man film had a July 20, 2018 release date, and would be produced by Lord and Miller, Avi Arad, Matt Tolmach, and Pascal, with Lord and Miller also writing a treatment for the film Rothman said that it would "co-exist" with the live-action Spider-Man films; though Sony soon stated that the film would "exist independently of the projects in the live-action Spider-Man universe", [41] as it is set in an alternate universe from those films, without the version of Spider-Man as seen in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) [42]


Writing
The script is credited to Lord and Rothman from a story by Lord, making it the first film Lord had written without Miller [50] As six Spider-Man films had been made already, the team agreed they first needed to decide why this one needed to be made; their answer was to tell the story of Morales, who had yet to appear in a film [51] Brian Michael Bendis, co-creator of Miles Morales, consulted on the film adaptation [52] The first full cut of animatics and storyboards for the film was over two hours long, which is uncommon for animated films The directors attributed this mostly to Lord and Miller, and their approach of adding as many elements to the film as they could at the outset, with the intention of seeing what it could "handle"; and then shaping the film from there They said that the final runtime would be between 90 and 120 minutes, the standard length of an animated film They added that a balance would have to be found between the expectations of an animated film that will have a large audience of children, and the requirements of the story The directors felt the plot was similar to the live-action Spider-Man films, especially due to the large number of characters in the film [51] One year prior to its release, Lord and Rothman opted to rewrite the story as they had to "figure out how to reshape sequences we had already boarded and animated and fold them in with new stuff" They also added that they had substantially rewritten the third act [53]


Casting
Shameik Moore was cast as Miles Morales in April 2017, along with Liev Schreiber as the film's then-unspecified main villain [7] A month later, Mahershala Ali and Brian Tyree Henry joined the cast as Morales's uncle Aaron Davis and father Jefferson Davis, respectively [13] That December, Lord and Miller said that an adult Peter Parker / Spider-Man would appear in the film as a mentor to Morales [58] Maguire, who played Spider-Man in the Sam Raimi films, was initially considered to be cast as this version of Spider-Man, but the idea was dropped so as not to confuse the audience with the concept of the "Spider-Verse" [59] Jake Johnson was ultimately cast in the role in April 2018 [10] It was also announced that the characters Green Goblin, Kingpin, and Prowler would also appear, with their designs based on the Ultimate Marvel comic series [60] Kathryn Hahn was cast as a female variant of Doctor Octopus called Olivia Octavius; earlier drafts for the film had the character's known male version as a The Big Lebowski (1998)-type of character, but Persichetti came up with changing the character's gender due to his kids being friends with Hahn's [61]


Music
Daniel Pemberton was announced as the film's composer in July 2018 [65] A full soundtrack album was released by Republic Records on December 14, the day of the film's release, and was curated to represent what a teen like Miles Morales would listen to [66] Artists on the soundtrack include Jaden Smith, Nicki Minaj, Lil Wayne, Post Malone, Ty Dolla Sign, Juice Wrld, Swae Lee, Ski Mask the Slump God, Vince Staples, Thutmose, and the late XXXTentacion, who was marketed as a special guest on the Lil Wayne and Ty Dolla Sign song "Scared of the Dark" A separate album containing Pemberton's score was released by Sony Classical Records on December 17 [67] On December 20, Sony Pictures Animation announced an extended play album, A Very Spidey Christmas, based on a throwaway joke at the beginning of the film and consisting of five Christmas songs performed by cast members Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson, and Chris Pine The EP was released on digital platforms the next day [68] [69]


Animation and design
The film's animation was handled by Sony Pictures Imageworks in Vancouver, who had handled nearly all of Sony Pictures Animation's prior films, as well as visual effects for all prior Spider-Man films According to Lord and Miller, they wanted the film to feel like the viewer had "walked inside a comic book", and were excited about telling the story in a way they believed the live-action films could not [58] Persichetti concurred, feeling that animation was the best medium to honor the comics, allowing the production team to adapt 70-year-old comic art techniques for the film's visual language [51] It took around a year for two animators to create 10 seconds of footage that reflected the producers' vision; the animation work was created from there [71] During initial development, the directors worked with a single animator, Alberto Mielgo, to establish the film's look [72] Although Mielgo was let go by Sony before the movie had been significantly produced due to artistic differences, [73] this number eventually grew to 60 animators during production It became clear that they could not complete the film on time, so the crew was expanded further The number had reached 142 animators by August 2018 [51] and at one point to 177 animators, [74] the largest animation crew that Sony Pictures Imageworks had ever used for a film Animation work was completed in October 2018 [51]


Release
A thirty-second sizzle reel from the film was shown at a Sony Pictures Animation presentation in January 2017, revealing that the film focuses on Miles Morales Scott Mendelson at Forbes said the footage "looked incredible   [sic] stylized and resembled a cross between an Alex Ross image and a psychedelic  [comic] cover", but felt the most significant element of the presentation was the confirmation of Morales, meaning "2018 will offer another comic book superhero movie featuring a hero of color, during the same year as Marvel's Black Panther." [46] A teaser trailer for the film debuted at the 2017 Comic Con Experience, and was then released online [49] Chris Cabin at Collider felt the trailer "looks much better than it ever needed to The style and design that is on display .. is vibrant and immediately engaging on a visual level, showing a genuine sense of personality to the production." [86] io9's Julie Muncy called the trailer's visual design "elegant" and "fresh", and highlighted the use of music by Vince Staples, which was also used for the Black Panther trailers [87]


Marketing
A thirty-second sizzle reel from the film was shown at a Sony Pictures Animation presentation in January 2017, revealing that the film focuses on Miles Morales Scott Mendelson at Forbes said the footage "looked incredible   [sic] stylized and resembled a cross between an Alex Ross image and a psychedelic  [comic] cover", but felt the most significant element of the presentation was the confirmation of Morales, meaning "2018 will offer another comic book superhero movie featuring a hero of color, during the same year as Marvel's Black Panther." [46] A teaser trailer for the film debuted at the 2017 Comic Con Experience, and was then released online [49] Chris Cabin at Collider felt the trailer "looks much better than it ever needed to The style and design that is on display .. is vibrant and immediately engaging on a visual level, showing a genuine sense of personality to the production." [86] io9's Julie Muncy called the trailer's visual design "elegant" and "fresh", and highlighted the use of music by Vince Staples, which was also used for the Black Panther trailers [87]


Theatrical
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse was released by Sony Pictures Releasing under its Columbia Pictures label on December 14, 2018 [48] [95] In April 2015, Sony had made its first official announcement that an animated Spider-Man film was in development, with a release date scheduled for July 20, 2018 [5] It is the first animated Spider-Man feature film, and is independent of the timelines of other Spider-Man universe films [5] At the end of 2015, the release date was changed to December 21, 2018, and was moved up by one week two years later [41] [43] [48] Sony premiered the film at the Regency Village Theater in Los Angeles on December 1, 2018, and included tributes to Stan Lee and Steve Ditko [4] [96] The film is dedicated to the memories of the creators of Spider-Man, Stan Lee and Steve Ditko, who both died in 2018.


Home media
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse was released on digital download by Sony Pictures Home Entertainment on February 26, 2019, with Blu-ray, Ultra HD Blu-ray, and DVD releases following on March 19 [97] All releases were accompanied by a short film featuring Spider-Ham entitled Caught in a Ham [98] An extended cut called the Alt-Universe Cut, featuring 30 minutes of unreleased footage, including some scenes with Miles' roommate, Ganke, and a deleted cameo with Tom Cruise and James Cameron, was also featured on its home video release [99] Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse was also released in Blu-ray 3D format in several regions, outside of the United States and United Kingdom, on April 10, 2019 [100]


Reception
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse grossed $190.2 million in the United States and Canada, and $194.0 million in other territories, for a total worldwide gross of $384.3 million, against a production budget of $90 million [3] On January 31, 2019, the film surpassed Hotel Transylvania 2 to become Sony Pictures Animation's highest-grossing film domestically, unadjusted for inflation [105]


Box office
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse grossed $190.2 million in the United States and Canada, and $194.0 million in other territories, for a total worldwide gross of $384.3 million, against a production budget of $90 million [3] On January 31, 2019, the film surpassed Hotel Transylvania 2 to become Sony Pictures Animation's highest-grossing film domestically, unadjusted for inflation [105]


Critical response
On Rotten Tomatoes, the film has an approval rating of 97% based on 403 reviews, with an average rating of 8.8/10 The website's critical consensus reads, "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse matches bold storytelling with striking animation for a purely enjoyable adventure with heart, humor, and plenty of superhero action" [111] It is the best-reviewed superhero film on the website [112] On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 87 out of 100 based on reviews from 50 critics, indicating "universal acclaim" [113] Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film a grade of "A+" on an A+ to F scale, and those at PostTrak gave it a 90% overall positive score, an 80% "definite recommend," and a 5 star rating [106]


Industry response and legacy
Actor Tom Holland, who plays Peter Parker / Spider-Man in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, praised Into the Spider-Verse as "one of the coolest films  [he has] ever seen," [123] and he would later reiterate his statement on the film in 2023, calling it "the best Spider-Man movie that's ever been made." [124] Chris Pratt, who worked with Lord and Miller on The Lego Movie films, described it as an "emotionally moving, cutting edge, progressive, diverse, funny, meta, action-packed, silly, visually stunning masterpiece!" [125] Comedian and actor Patton Oswalt, who worked with Lord and Miller on 22 Jump Street (2014) and appeared on Marvel's Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D (2013–2020), called the film "brilliant," and continued, "This has been a non-stop year for me and I'm glad I'm ending it in such a cinematic high-note Not only is it the best superhero film ever made, it's flat-out a game-changing MOVIE Seeing it again tomorrow!" [126] Kevin Smith reviewed the film on his podcast Fatman Beyond, stating, "I always liked Spider-Man but this movie made me love Spider-Man on a Batman-type level," and continued, "It just goes to show you that any character in the right hands can be a transformative experience." [127] Barry Jenkins, writer and director of the Academy Award-winning film Moonlight (2016, which also starred Ali), praised the film, calling it "magnificent" and citing it as the best Spider-Man film, one of the best films of 2018, and the best tentpole film since Edge of Tomorrow (2014) Jenkins continued, saying, "I was stupefied I mean just tremendous, tremendous work, so grounded and full of verve; visceral Saw it on the biggest screen I could find, just a viscerally enthralling experience I salute you." [128] Rian Johnson, writer and director of Star Wars: The Last Jedi (2017), described the film as "the Velvet Underground of superhero movies", believing it will be an influential film [129] [130] James Gunn, writer and director of Guardians of the Galaxy (2014), has named Into the Spider-Verse his favorite superhero film [131] Marvel Studios president and MCU producer Kevin Feige said that he "loved it." [132] Many other filmmakers including Edgar Wright, Guillermo del Toro, Yance Ford, and RaMell Ross have listed the film as one of their favorites of 2018 [133]


Accolades
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse won Best Animated Feature Film at the 76th Golden Globe Awards, [148] and won the same award at the 24th Critics' Choice Awards [149] and the 91st Academy Awards, [150] among several other awards and nominations It was the first non-Disney or Pixar film to win Best Animated Feature since Rango (2011), becoming the 6th non-Disney/Pixar film to win the award [151] It was similarly successful at the 76th Golden Globe Awards, the 72nd British Academy Film Awards, and the 46th Annie Awards 


Franchise
Following the "incredible buzz" of Into the Spider-Verse, Sony led to the development on a sequel [75] Its story was split into two films to address the follow-up's excessive length [155] Into the Spider-Verse was followed by Across the Spider-Verse, released on June 2, 2023, [156] after being delayed twice from an original 2022 date [157] The film surpassed the box-office take of Into the Spider-Verse, [158] and received a similarly positive critical and audience response [159] The third film, Beyond the Spider-Verse, is in production [160]


Sequels
Following the "incredible buzz" of Into the Spider-Verse, Sony led to the development on a sequel [75] Its story was split into two films to address the follow-up's excessive length [155] Into the Spider-Verse was followed by Across the Spider-Verse, released on June 2, 2023, [156] after being delayed twice from an original 2022 date [157] The film surpassed the box-office take of Into the Spider-Verse, [158] and received a similarly positive critical and audience response [159] The third film, Beyond the Spider-Verse, is in production [160]


Spin-offs
In 2018, Sony announced a spin-off animated film based on the Spider-Women comics, focusing on three generations of female Spider-related characters, [161] including Spider-Gwen, Jessica Drew / Spider-Woman, and Cindy Moon / Silk [54] Bek Smith is attached as a screenwriter and Lauren Montgomery was in talks to direct [54] [75] [161] Lord and Miller were confirmed to be producing the film in April 2021, when the project was undergoing rewrites [162] Pascal and Arad reaffirmed that the film was in development in May 2023, when Arad said it would be made sooner than expected, while Steinfeld expressed interest in the film [163]


Possible television series
Following the release of Into the Spider-Verse, the studio discussed the possibility of television series featuring the characters Lord and Miller both expressed interest in seeing a series of shorts starring Spider-Ham, [165] while Sony was announced to be developing animated spin-off TV series focusing on various characters [166] By April 2019, Lord and Miller signed a five-year deal with Sony Pictures Television to create animated Marvel television series alongside Sony Pictures Animation, including a possible TV series based on Into the Spider-Verse [167] Discussing these series in August 2019, Miller could not update where or when the series would be released but said there would be several live-action series and that they would each be "their own unique experience" while still being related to each other [168]


Notes


References


External links
article:
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a 2018 American animated superhero film directed by Bob Persichetti, Peter Ramsey, and Rodney Rothman. The film is produced by Sony Pictures Animation in association with Marvel Entertainment, LLC and is the first animated film in the Spider-Man franchise.

**Introduction**

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a groundbreaking film that combines stunning animation, engaging storylines, and memorable characters. The film follows the journey of Miles Morales, a teenager who becomes the new Spider-Man, as he navigates a multiverse of Spider-Men and battles the villainous Kingpin. With its unique visual style, witty humor, and heart-pumping action sequences, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse has become a fan favorite and a critical success.

**Plot**

The film begins with Miles Morales, a shy and introverted teenager, struggling to live up to the expectations of his father, a police officer. Miles' life takes a dramatic turn when he is bitten by a radioactive spider, giving him incredible powers similar to Spider-Man. As Miles learns to navigate his new abilities, he discovers a mysterious collider built by Kingpin, who aims to access parallel universes to abduct alternate versions of his late wife and son.

Spider-Man, aka Peter Parker, attempts to disable the collider while fighting Kingpin's enforcers, the Green Goblin and Prowler.
