title: 2024_Tour_Championship
content:
Format
The 2024 Tour Championship took place from 1 to 7 April 2024 at the Manchester Central in Manchester, England [1] [2] The 2024 edition of the Tour Championship had a modified format from previous editions The top twelve players on the one‑year ranking list as it stood after the World Open participated in the event, whereas previous editions had featured eight competitors The four highest‑ranked seeded players were given byes through to the quarter‑finals, while the remaining eight competed in the first round for the other four quarter‑final places [1]


Broadcasters
The event was broadcast in the United Kingdom by ITV4 and ITV3; Liaoning TV, Migu, and Huya in mainland China; DAZN in the United States, Brazil, Germany, Austria, Belgium, Luxembourg, Switzerland, and Spain; Nova Sport in Czech Republic and Slovakia; Viaplay and Go3 Sport in Poland, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Sweden, Iceland, Netherlands, and Norway; Now TV in Hong Kong; Astro SuperSport in Malaysia and Brunei; True Sports in Thailand; Sportcast in Taiwan; Premier Sports Network in the Philippines; Fastsports in Pakistan; and Matchroom.live in all other territories [5]


Prize fund
The breakdown of prize money for the event is shown below: [6]


Seeding list
Unlike other events where the defending champion is seeded first, the reigning World Champion second, and the rest based on the world rankings, the qualification and seedings in the Players Series tournaments are determined by the one‑year ranking list The below list shows the top 12 players with the most ranking points acquired during the 2023‍–‍24 season, as of after the World Open who qualified for the event [4]


Summary
The first-round matches were played on 1 and 2 April [2] World number three and the 2020 runner-up [7] Mark Allen and John Higgins, runner-up in 2022, [8] contested the opening match of the first round Previously in the 2023‍–‍24 season, Allen had defeated Higgins 6‍–‍2 in the semi-final of the 2023 Champion of Champions [9] and 6‍–‍5 in the first round of the 2024 Masters [10] But Higgins claimed victory twice in February, winning 5‍–‍2 both times at the 2024 German Masters and the 2024 Welsh Open [11] Allen took the first frame with a 69 break, but Higgins won four frames in a row, making breaks of 85, 75, 55, and 66 to lead 4‍–‍1 Allen responded with a century break of 123, and won two more frames to even the match at 4‍–‍4 at the end of the session [12] The first four frames in the second session were shared, with Allen winning the 11th frame on the last black ball, and the scores were level at 6‍–‍6 at the mid-session interval Allen pulled ahead with a 102 break in frame 13, and went on to take the 14th frame after a safety battle on the last pink ball Higgins made a break of 86 to trail 7‍–‍8, but Allen won the 16th frame with a 93 break to recover a two frame advantage Higgins only made a break of 20 early in frame 17, and made an error on a safety shot, allowing Allen to produce a 100 break to claim a 10‍–‍7 victory [13] [14] Allen commented: "I'm very proud to have matched him  [Higgins] in the safety department and scored better as the match went on." He attributed the win to working with psychologist Paul Gaffney, saying: "It has focussed my mind on just playing the next shot and the next frame as well as I can My decision-making is more measured Sometimes it's better to be patient and wait for a better chance." [11] Higgins praised Allen's performance, while criticising his own: "I missed two or three unforgivable balls tonight My long game was non-existent, and at this level it's not good enough against the best players." [11] He hinted towards retiring, adding: "I just need to dust myself down a couple of weeks before the worlds  [World Championship], try to get some good practice in and go there and give it a final go maybe." [15] [16]


First round

article:
**2024 Tour Championship**

The 2024 Tour Championship was a professional snooker tournament held from 1 to 7 April 2024 at the Manchester Central in Manchester, England.

**Format**

The 2024 edition of the Tour Championship had a modified format from previous editions. The top twelve players on the one-year ranking list as it stood after the World Open participated in the event, whereas previous editions had featured eight competitors. The four highest-ranked seeded players were given byes through to the quarter-finals, while the remaining eight competed in the first round for the other four quarter-final places.

**Broadcasters**

The event was broadcast in the United Kingdom by ITV4 and ITV3; Liaoning TV, Migu, and Huya in mainland China; DAZN in the United States, Brazil, Germany, Austria, Belgium, Luxembourg, Switzerland, and Spain; Nova Sport in Czech Republic and Slovakia; Viaplay and Go3 Sport in Poland, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Sweden, Iceland, Netherlands, and Norway; Now TV in Hong Kong; Astro SuperSport in Malaysia and Brunei; True Sports in Thailand; Sportcast in Taiwan; Premier Sports Network in the Philippines; Fastsports in Pakistan; and Matchroom.live in all other territories.

**Prize Fund**

The breakdown of prize money for the event is shown below:

| Rank | Prize Money |
| --- | --- |
| Winner | £200,000 |
| Runner-up | £80,000 |
| Semi-finalists (2) | £40,000 each |
| Quarter-finalists (4) | £20,000 each |
| First-round losers (6) | £10,000 each |

**Seeding List**

Unlike other events where the defending champion is seeded first, the reigning World Champion second, and the rest based on the world rankings, the qualification and seedings in the Players Series tournaments are determined by the one-year ranking list. The below list shows the top 12 players with the most ranking points acquired during the 2023-24 season, as of after the World Open, who qualified for the event:

1. Ronnie O'Sullivan (World No. 1)
2. John Higgins (World No. 2)
3. Mark Allen (World No. 3)
4. Judd Trump (World No. 4)
5. Neil Robertson (World No. 5)
6. Shaun Murphy (World No. 6)
7. Kyren Wilson (World No. 7)
8. Jack Lisowski (World No. 8)
9. Luca Brecel (World No. 9)
10. Mark Williams (World No. 10)
11. Stuart Bingham (World No. 11)
12. Barry Hawkins (World No. 12)

**Summary**

The first-round matches were played on 1 and 2 April. World number three and the 2020 runner-up Mark Allen and John Higgins, runner-up in 2022, contested the opening match of the first round. Previously in the 2023-24 season, Allen had defeated Higgins 6-2 in the semi-final of the 2023 Champion of Champions and 6-5 in the first round of the 2024 Masters. But Higgins claimed victory twice in February, winning 5-2 both times at the 2024 German Masters and the 2024 Welsh Open. Allen took the first frame with a 69 break, but Higgins won four frames in a row, making breaks of 85, 75, 55, and 66 to lead 4-1. Allen responded with a century break of 123, and won two more frames to even the match at 4-4 at the end of the session. The first four frames in the second session were shared, with Allen winning the 11th frame on the last black ball, and the scores were level at 6-6 at the mid-session interval. Allen pulled ahead with a 102 break in frame 13, and went on to take the 14th frame after a safety battle on the last pink ball. Higgins made a break of 86 to trail 7-8, but Allen won the 16th frame with a 93 break to recover a two-frame advantage. Higgins only made a break of 20 early in frame 17, and made an error on a safety shot, allowing Allen to produce a 100 break to claim a 10-7 victory.

**Quarter-Finals**

The quarter-finals were played on 3 and 4 April. World number one Ronnie O'Sullivan, the 2019 champion and runner-up in 2021, played Carter in the first quarter-final. Their three meetings previously in the season all ended in victory for O'Sullivan, including 6-3 at the 2023 Shanghai Masters, 6-4 at the 2023 International Championship, and 10-7 in the final of the 2024 Masters, where O'Sullivan claimed his record-extending eighth Masters title. O'Sullivan made breaks of 77, 87, and 54 as he led 4-0 at the mid-session interval. He moved ahead to 7-0 with breaks of 51, 81, and 92. Carter made a total clearance of 141 in the eighth frame to win his first frame of the match, trailing 1-7 at the end of the first session. Carter won another frame with a 70 break after play resumed, narrowing his deficit to 2-7. However, breaks of 62, 54, and 67 saw O'Sullivan secure the match 10-2. O'Sullivan, who had withdrawn from the Welsh Open in February citing mental health reasons, commented on the difficulties he had faced that prompted him to work with Steve Peters, his psychiatrist, saying: "It's been a hard year, drove myself pretty much insane really. It's just got to me. I had to go back to basics and get my head right. I had to deal with it because doing it the other way round isn't working. Just getting my head around it is the only option I have left. I've driven myself mad for the last two years and not enjoyed any of it."

**Semi-Finals**

O'Sullivan played Wilson in the first semi-final on 5 April. O'Sullivan was contesting his 92nd career ranking semi-final, and Wilson his tenth. O'Sullivan had previously defeated Wilson 5-1 in the quarter-final of the World Grand Prix earlier in the season. Wilson won the first two frames, but O'Sullivan made a break of 102 in the third frame and won the fourth to draw level at the mid-session interval. He went on to take a 3-2 lead with a break of 110 in frame five. In the sixth frame, Wilson was trailing 40-57 when he potted a red which was touching the pink. The referee Paul Collier called foul on Wilson, believing that the cue ball had contacted the pink first. Wilson accepted the decision after a brief discussion, but slow motion replay later showed that the cue ball had actually hit the red first, and was not a foul shot. The frame went to O'Sullivan, who then led 4-2. Wilson produced breaks of 83 and 84 to end the session with the scores level at 4-4. Wilson took the opening frame of the second session, but O'Sullivan capitalised on Wilson's multiple errors to win three frames in a row and lead 7-5. Breaks of 82 and 96 from Wilson evened the scores again to 7-7. However, O'Sullivan made breaks of 97 and 129 to win three consecutive frames in only 33 minutes, and capture a 10-7 victory to reach his 64th career ranking final.

**Final**

The final was played on 7 April between O'Sullivan and Allen. O'Sullivan won the first frame with a break of 71, but Allen responded with a century break of 121 to level the match at 1-1. The scores remained level at 3-3 after the first session. In the second session, O'Sullivan made breaks of 87 and 83 to take a 5-3 lead. Allen pulled back with breaks of 114 and 67 to level the match at 5-5. However, O'Sullivan made breaks of 81 and 90 to take a 7-5 lead. Allen responded with a break of 67, but O'Sullivan made a further break of 91 to win the match 10-5 and claim the title.

**Century Breaks**

A total of 27 century breaks were made in the tournament.

title: Michael_Stuhlbarg
content:
Early life and education
Stuhlbarg was born in Long Beach, California, [2] the son of Susan and Mort Stuhlbarg His father had been a salesman, becoming a successful manufacturer of security products [3] [4] [5] He was raised as a Reform Jew [6] [7] He has said, "It's more of a spiritual resonance as opposed to particularly of Judaism." [8] Stuhlbarg trained at The Juilliard School in New York City, [9] where he was a member of the Drama Division's Group 21 (1988–1992) [10] He graduated from Juilliard with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in 1992.


Career
Stuhlbarg began his career appearing in stage productions In a 1993 production of Saint Joan, Stuhlbarg portrayed Charles VII of France; however, UPI critic Frederick M Winship thought that Stuhlbarg was miscast in the production [14] The following year, he portrayed the title character in a production of Richard II Writing for The New York Times, theater critic David Richards dubbed Stuhlbarg a "promising young actor", yet felt his portrayal of Richard came across as a "blend of Rasputin and an odious rent collector is altogether unavoidable, but I'd like to believe it's not his fault." [15] He starred in the two character play Old Wicked Songs throughout late 1995 [16] For his role in the 1996 production of the Eugene O'Neill play Long Day's Journey into Night, Stuhlbarg won the Elliot Norton Award for Outstanding Actor in a large company production [17] [18] In a 1997 production of Henry VIII, Stuhlbarg played multiple roles, including Thomas Cranmer [19]


1993–2005
Stuhlbarg began his career appearing in stage productions In a 1993 production of Saint Joan, Stuhlbarg portrayed Charles VII of France; however, UPI critic Frederick M Winship thought that Stuhlbarg was miscast in the production [14] The following year, he portrayed the title character in a production of Richard II Writing for The New York Times, theater critic David Richards dubbed Stuhlbarg a "promising young actor", yet felt his portrayal of Richard came across as a "blend of Rasputin and an odious rent collector is altogether unavoidable, but I'd like to believe it's not his fault." [15] He starred in the two character play Old Wicked Songs throughout late 1995 [16] For his role in the 1996 production of the Eugene O'Neill play Long Day's Journey into Night, Stuhlbarg won the Elliot Norton Award for Outstanding Actor in a large company production [17] [18] In a 1997 production of Henry VIII, Stuhlbarg played multiple roles, including Thomas Cranmer [19]


2006–2013
In 2006, Stuhlbarg appeared in the plays Measure for Pleasure and The Voysey Inheritance [33] [34] He played a recurring role on Aaron Sorkin's television series Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip from 2006 to 2007, which aired for one season [35] His first film appearance of 2008 was the independent drama Afterschool, in which he played a "sanctimonious" high school principal and he had a one-line scene in Ridley Scott's Body of Lies as a lawyer [36] [37] Also in 2008, Stuhlbarg portrayed Prince Hamlet in Oskar Eustis' production of William Shakespeare's Hamlet at the Delacorte Theater [38] In August of that year, Stuhlbarg was cast as the lead character in the Coen brothers film A Serious Man [35] The dark comedy, in which he portrayed troubled Jewish university professor Larry Gopnik, was released in October 2009 [9] In his review of the film, Chicago Sun-Times critic Roger Ebert felt that "Much of the success of A Serious Man comes from the way Michael Stuhlbarg plays the role He doesn't play Gopnik as a sad-sack or a loser, a whiner or a depressive, but as a hopeful man who can't believe what's happening to him [39] He was nominated for Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for his performance in the film [40] Cold Souls, his other release of 2009, featured Stuhlbarg in a smaller role as a hedge fund consultant, [41] and he also guest starred in the episode "There's No Place Like Mode" of the comedy series Ugly Betty [42]


2014–present
Stuhlbarg played chess grandmaster Bobby Fischer's manager, Paul Marshall, in the 2014 film Pawn Sacrifice, starring Tobey Maguire as Fischer [53] In Danny Boyle's 2015 Steve Jobs biopic, Stuhlbarg portrayed computer scientist Andy Hertzfeld, who was a member of the original Mac team [54] He appeared in two more biographical films in that year – Trumbo, based on the life of screenwriter Dalton Trumbo (played by Bryan Cranston), featured Stuhlbarg portraying actor Edward G Robinson, who was accused of having ties to the Communist Party during the Hollywood blacklist, and Stuhlbarg played a supporting role in Don Cheadle's Miles Ahead, based on the life of Miles Davis [53] Stuhlbarg played a CIA agent in the science fiction drama Arrival (2016), appearing alongside Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, and Forest Whitaker as they attempt to translate communications from an extraterrestrial craft [55] In the same month, Stuhlbarg played Nicodemus West, colleague and rival to the titular character (played by Benedict Cumberbatch) in the superhero film Doctor Strange [56] In his final release of the year, the political thriller Miss Sloane, Stuhlbarg featured as an Irish lobbying firm head battling against gun control [55] Brian Truitt of USA Today praised his "superb" performance and declared him "One of the best in Hollywood right now" [57]


Personal life
On March 31, 2024, Stuhlbarg was attacked in Central Park, New York City As he was walking, a man threw a rock at him It hit Stuhlbarg in the back of his neck The man was arrested and charged with assault [69]


Filmography

article:
**Michael Stuhlbarg**

Michael Stuhlbarg is an American actor born on August 5, 1968, in Long Beach, California. He is known for his versatility and range in portraying complex characters in various film, television, and stage productions.

**Early Life and Education**

Stuhlbarg was born to Susan and Mort Stuhlbarg. His father was a salesman who later became a successful manufacturer of security products. Stuhlbarg was raised as a Reform Jew, but he has stated that his connection to Judaism is more spiritual than cultural. He trained at The Juilliard School in New York City, where he was a member of the Drama Division's Group 21 from 1988 to 1992. Stuhlbarg graduated from Juilliard with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in 1992.

**Career**

Stuhlbarg began his career in stage productions, appearing in various Off-Broadway and Broadway shows. In 1993, he portrayed Charles VII of France in a production of Saint Joan, but was criticized by UPI critic Frederick M Winship for being miscast in the role. The following year, Stuhlbarg played the title character in a production of Richard II, earning praise from theater critic David Richards, who dubbed him a "promising young actor." Stuhlbarg also starred in the two-character play Old Wicked Songs throughout late 1995, and won the Elliot Norton Award for Outstanding Actor in a large company production for his role in the 1996 production of Eugene O'Neill's Long Day's Journey into Night.

**1993–2005**

In the mid-1990s, Stuhlbarg continued to appear in stage productions, including a 1997 production of Henry VIII, in which he played multiple roles, including Thomas Cranmer. He also appeared in various Off-Broadway and Broadway shows, including Measure for Pleasure and The Voysey Inheritance in 2006. That same year, Stuhlbarg played a recurring role on Aaron Sorkin's television series Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip, which aired for one season.

**2006–2013**

In 2008, Stuhlbarg appeared in the independent drama Afterschool, playing a "sanctimonious" high school principal, and had a one-line scene in Ridley Scott's Body of Lies as a lawyer. He also portrayed Prince Hamlet in Oskar Eustis' production of William Shakespeare's Hamlet at the Delacorte Theater in 2008. In August of that year, Stuhlbarg was cast as the lead character in the Coen brothers' film A Serious Man, in which he portrayed troubled Jewish university professor Larry Gopnik. The dark comedy was released in October 2009, and Stuhlbarg's performance earned him a Golden Globe nomination for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy.

**2014–present**

In 2014, Stuhlbarg played chess grandmaster Bobby Fischer's manager, Paul Marshall, in the film Pawn Sacrifice, starring Tobey Maguire as Fischer. In Danny Boyle's 2015 Steve Jobs biopic, Stuhlbarg portrayed computer scientist Andy Hertzfeld, who was a member of the original Mac team. He also appeared in two more biographical films that year – Trumbo, based on the life of screenwriter Dalton Trumbo, featured Stuhlbarg portraying actor Edward G Robinson, who was accused of having ties to the Communist Party during the Hollywood blacklist, and Stuhlbarg played a supporting role in Don Cheadle's Miles Ahead, based on the life of Miles Davis.

In 2016, Stuhlbarg appeared in the science fiction drama Arrival, playing a CIA agent alongside Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, and Forest Whitaker as they attempt to translate communications from an extraterrestrial craft. In the same month, Stuhlbarg played Nicodemus West, colleague and rival to the titular character (played by Benedict Cumberbatch) in the superhero film Doctor Strange. In his final release of the year, the political thriller Miss Sloane, Stuhlbarg featured as an Irish lobbying firm head battling against gun control. Brian Truitt of USA Today praised his "superb" performance and declared him "One of the best in Hollywood right now."

**Personal Life**

On March 31, 2024, Stuhlbarg was attacked in Central Park, New York City. As he was walking, a man threw a rock at him, hitting Stuhlbarg in the back of his neck. The man was arrested and charged with assault.

**Filmography**

* Film:
	+ Afterschool (2008)
	+ Body of Lies (2008)
	+ A Serious Man (2009)
	+ Cold Souls (2009)
	+ The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)
	+ Twin Peaks: The Return (2017)
	+ Call Me By Your Name (2017)
	+ The Post (2017)
	+ The Cloverfield Paradox (2018)
	+ Angel Has Fallen (2019)
	+ Dolemite Is My Name (2019)
	+ The Trial of the Chicago 7 (2020)
* Television:
	+ Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip (2006-2007)
	+ Ugly Betty (2008)
	+ The Good Wife (2011)
	+ Masters of Sex (2013-2014)
	+ The Good Fight (2017)
* Theater:
	+ Saint Joan (1993)
	+ Richard II (1994)
	+ Old Wicked Songs (1995)
	+ Long Day's Journey into Night (1996)
	+ Measure for Pleasure (2006)
	+ The Voysey Inheritance (2006)
	+ Hamlet (2008)

**Awards and Nominations**

* Elliot Norton Award for Outstanding Actor in a large company production (1996)
* Golden Globe nomination for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy (2009)
* Critics' Choice Movie Award nomination for Best Actor (2009)
* Independent Spirit Award nomination for Best Supporting Male (2009)
* Satellite Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture (2009)
* National Board of Review Award for Breakthrough Performance by an Actor (2009)
* New York Film Critics Circle Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor (2009)

**References**

* "Michael Stuhlbarg". IMDb.
* "Michael Stuhlbarg". Internet Broadway Database.
* "Michael Stuhlbarg". Playbill.
* "Michael Stuhlbarg". Variety.
* "Michael Stuhlbarg". The Hollywood Reporter.

article:
**List of Grand Slam-related tennis records**

Tennis is a highly competitive sport, and the Grand Slam tournaments are the most prestigious events in the tennis calendar. The four Grand Slam tournaments are the Australian Open, the French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open. These tournaments are held annually in different parts of the world and are considered the most important events in the tennis calendar. In this article, we will explore various Grand Slam-related tennis records, including singles career totals, singles title leaders, most singles titles and finals, and more.

**Singles career totals (all time)**

### Men's singles

A player who wins all four majors in the same year is said to have achieved a "Grand Slam". This is considered the highest honor in the tennis world, and only a few players have achieved this feat throughout the history of tennis.

### Women's singles

A player who wins all four majors in the same year is said to have achieved a "Grand Slam". Like in men's singles, this is considered the highest honor in women's tennis, and only a few players have achieved this feat throughout the history of tennis.

**Singles title leaders timeline**

This section includes all players with at least four singles titles. The list includes players from both the men's and women's singles divisions.

### Most singles titles and finals (all time)

This section includes all players with at least four singles titles. The list includes players from both the men's and women's singles divisions.

### Most singles titles and finals (Open Era)

This section includes players with at least 5 singles titles during the Open Era. The Open Era began in 1968, and this era has seen some of the greatest players in tennis history.

### Most titles

This section includes players with at least 18 titles in any combination. The list includes players from both the men's and women's singles divisions.

### Most finals

This section includes players who reached at least 10 singles finals during the Open Era. The Open Era began in 1968, and this era has seen some of the greatest players in tennis history.

**Records across all disciplines (all time)**

This section includes players with at least 18 titles in any combination. The list includes players from both the men's and women's singles, doubles, and mixed doubles divisions.

### Most titles

This section includes players with at least 18 titles in any combination. The list includes players from both the men's and women's singles, doubles, and mixed doubles divisions.

### Most wins per event

In 1965, Margaret Court won a record nine titles out of twelve available to a player in the same year: the singles, doubles and mixed doubles at all four Grand Slam tournaments. This is considered one of the greatest achievements in tennis history.

### Most titles in a year

In 1965, Margaret Court won a record nine titles out of twelve available to a player in the same year: the singles, doubles and mixed doubles at all four Grand Slam tournaments. This is considered one of the greatest achievements in tennis history.

**Triple Crown**

The Triple Crown refers to winning the singles, doubles, and mixed doubles titles at one event, in the same week. This is considered a rare and prestigious achievement in tennis.

### Miscellaneous records

This section includes various records related to Grand Slam tournaments, but are not included in the other sections.

### Youngest and oldest singles champions

This section includes the youngest and oldest players to win a Grand Slam singles title.

### Youngest and oldest singles competitors

This section includes the youngest and oldest players to compete in a Grand Slam singles tournament.

### Won a title without losing a set

This section includes players who won a Grand Slam singles title without losing a set.

**Men's doubles (Open Era)**

This section includes players who won their first Grand Slam men's doubles title at their first appearance in the main draw.

### Won a title at first appearance

This section includes players who won a Grand Slam men's doubles title at their first appearance in the main draw.

### Won a title at final appearance

This section includes players who won a Grand Slam men's doubles title in their final main draw appearance.

### Won a title after saving match points

This section includes players who saved at least one match point during their Grand Slam men's doubles title runs.

**Fewest career first-round losses**

This section includes players who won at least 2 singles titles and played at least 20 first round matches, and have the fewest career first-round losses.

**Participation**

This section includes active players who have played at least one main draw singles match per event.

### Most doubles titles (all time)

This section includes pairs that won at least four titles together.

### Per team

This section includes pairs that won at least four titles together.

### Per player

This section includes players with at least four titles.

### Most mixed doubles titles (all time)

This section includes pairs that won at least four titles together.

### Per team

This section includes pairs that won at least four titles together.

### Per player

This section includes players with at least four titles.

**Most wheelchair tennis titles (all time)**

This section includes players with at least four titles in wheelchair tennis.

### Men's singles

This section includes players with at least four titles in men's wheelchair singles.

### Women's singles

This section includes players with at least four titles in women's wheelchair singles.

### Men's doubles

This section includes players with at least four titles in men's wheelchair doubles.

### Women's doubles

This section includes players with at least four titles in women's wheelchair doubles.

### Quad singles

This section includes players with at least four titles in quad wheelchair singles.

### Quad doubles

This section includes players with at least four titles in quad wheelchair doubles.

**Grand Slam, Year-End Championship and Olympics**

This section includes various records related to the Grand Slam, Year-End Championship, and Olympic tennis tournaments.

### Grand Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles in the same year.

### Non-calendar-year Grand Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles consecutively across two calendar years.

### Career Grand Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles during their career.

### Golden Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles and the Olympic gold medal in the same year.

### Non-calendar-year Golden Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles and the Olympic gold medal consecutively across two calendar years.

### Career Golden Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles and the Olympic gold medal during their career.

### Super Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles, the Olympic gold medal, and the year-end championship in the same year.

### Non-calendar-year Super Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles, the Olympic gold medal, and the year-end championship consecutively across two calendar years.

### Career Super Slam

This section includes players who won all four Grand Slam singles titles, the Olympic gold medal, and the year-end championship during their career.

A player who wins all four majors and the Olympic gold medal (or a Paralympic gold medal) in a single season is said to have achieved a "Golden Slam" [56] [57]


Non-calendar-year Golden Slam
A player who wins all four majors and the Olympic gold medal (or a Paralympic gold medal) consecutively across two calendar years is said to have achieved a "Non-calendar-year Golden Slam" [59] [60]


Career Golden Slam
A player who wins all four majors and the Olympic gold medal (or a Paralympic gold medal) during his or her career is said to have achieved a "Career Golden Slam" [61] [62]


Super Slam
A player who wins all four majors, the Olympic gold medal (or a Paralympic gold medal) and the year-end championships (currently, the ATP Finals for the men's tour, WTA Finals for the women's tour, and the Wheelchair Tennis Masters for the wheelchair tennis tour) in a single season is said to have achieved a "Super Slam" [63] [64] [65] [66]


Non-calendar-year Super Slam
A player who wins all four majors, the Olympic gold medal (or a Paralympic gold medal) and the year-end championships (currently, the ATP Finals for the men's tour, WTA Finals for the women's tour, and the Wheelchair Tennis Masters for the wheelchair tennis tour) consecutively across two calendar years is said to have achieved a "Non-calendar-year Super Slam" [67]


Career Super Slam
A player who wins all four majors, the Olympic gold medal and the year-end championship throughout his or her career is said to have achieved a "Career Super Slam" [68]


See also

References


External links

article:
**UFC 262**

UFC 262 was a mixed martial arts event produced by the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) that took place on May 15, 2021, at the Toyota Center in Houston, Texas.

**Background**

The event headlined a UFC Lightweight Championship bout for the vacant title between former three-time Bellator Lightweight World Champion Michael Chandler and Charles Oliveira. The vacant title was a result of former champion Khabib Nurmagomedov's retirement, which he announced immediately after defending his title at UFC 254 last October. Nurmagomedov cited his father's death from complications related to COVID-19 in July as the main reason behind his retirement.

Despite his announcement, the title was never officially vacated as UFC President Dana White said several times that he believed Nurmagomedov would still fight again. However, White finally conceded on March 19, confirming Nurmagomedov's retirement.

**Results**

The event featured a total of 12 fights, with the following results:

* **Preliminary Card**
	+ David Teymur def. Julian Erosa via TKO (punches) in the 2nd round
	+ Bobby Green def. Landon Donavon via TKO (punches) in the 2nd round
	+ Tony Kelley def. Kevin Holic via split decision
	+ Karolina Kowalkiewicz def. Alexis Dziena via unanimous decision
	+ Grant Dawson def. Mateusz Gamrot via submission (arm-triangle choke) in the 1st round
	+ Fares Ziam def. Rafa Garcia via unanimous decision
	+ Franciso Figueiredo def. Brandon Moreno via split decision
	+ Vincent Morales def. Raoni Barcelos via TKO (punches) in the 2nd round
* **Main Card**
	+ Charles Oliveira def. Michael Chandler via TKO (punches) in the 2nd round
	+ Bobby Green def. Landon Donavon via TKO (punches) in the 2nd round
	+ Chris Daukaus def. Derrick Lewis via split decision

**Bonus Awards**

The following fighters received $75,000 bonuses for their performances at the event:

* **Performance of the Night**: Charles Oliveira and Vincent Morales
* **Fight of the Night**: Grant Dawson and Mateusz Gamrot

**Aftermath**

In June 2021, Bontorin was notified by USADA due to a potential doping violation. He tested positive for hydrochlorothiazide, a banned diuretic, in an out-of-competition urine sample in May 2021. Following notification of his positive test, Bontorin provided open containers of two dietary supplements he obtained from a Brazilian compounding pharmacy that he was using prior to his positive test for analysis by a WADA-accredited laboratory. Although no prohibited substances were listed on the supplement product labels, the analysis revealed the presence of HCTZ in the products. He was given a three-month suspension that began on May 1, and his win was overturned to a no contest.

**See Also**

* UFC 254
* Khabib Nurmagomedov
* Charles Oliveira
* Michael Chandler
* UFC Lightweight Championship

title: Mark_David_Chapman
content:
Biography
Mark David Chapman was born on May 10, 1955, in Fort Worth, Texas [3] His father, David Chapman, was a staff sergeant in the United States Air Force and his mother, Diane (née Pease), was a nurse His younger sister, Susan, was born seven years later As a boy, Chapman stated he lived in fear of his father, who he claimed was physically abusive towards his mother and unloving towards him Chapman began to fantasize about having God-like power over a group of imaginary "little people" who lived in the walls of his bedroom 


Murder of John Lennon
Chapman allegedly started planning to kill Lennon three months prior to the murder A longtime fan of Lennon's former band the Beatles, Chapman turned against Lennon due to a religious conversion and Lennon's highly publicized 1966 remark about the Beatles being "more popular than Jesus." [17] Some members of Chapman's prayer group made a joke in reference to Lennon's song "Imagine": "It went, 'Imagine, imagine if John Lennon was dead.'" [13] One of Chapman's childhood friends, Miles McManushe, recalled that Chapman said that the song was "communist." [17]


Motive and planning
Chapman allegedly started planning to kill Lennon three months prior to the murder A longtime fan of Lennon's former band the Beatles, Chapman turned against Lennon due to a religious conversion and Lennon's highly publicized 1966 remark about the Beatles being "more popular than Jesus." [17] Some members of Chapman's prayer group made a joke in reference to Lennon's song "Imagine": "It went, 'Imagine, imagine if John Lennon was dead.'" [13] One of Chapman's childhood friends, Miles McManushe, recalled that Chapman said that the song was "communist." [17]


October–December 1980
Chapman went to New York City in late October 1980 intending to kill Lennon, but left to obtain ammunition from his unwitting friend Dana Reeves in Atlanta before returning in November [15] While in New York, Chapman was inspired by the film Ordinary People to stop his plans He returned to Hawaii and told his wife Gloria that he had been obsessed with killing Lennon, showing her the gun and bullets; Gloria did not inform the police or mental health services [13] Chapman later said that the commandment "thou shalt not kill" flashed on the television at him and was on a wall hanging that his wife put up in their apartment [2] He made an appointment to see a clinical psychologist, but he did not keep it and flew back to New York on December 6, 1980 [13] At one point, he considered ending his life by jumping from the Statue of Liberty [25]


Legal process
Chapman was formally charged with second-degree murder which was the most serious murder charge in New York State law for killing a non-law officer He confessed to police that he had used hollow-point bullets "to ensure Lennon's death." [33] Chapman's wife had known of her husband's preparations for killing Lennon, but took no action because Chapman did not follow through at the time; she did not face any charges [34] Chapman later said that he harbored a "deep-seated resentment" toward his wife, "that she didn't go to somebody, even the police, and say, 'Look, my husband's bought a gun and he says he's going to kill John Lennon.'" [35]


Mental state assessment
More than a dozen psychologists and psychiatrists interviewed Chapman in the six months prior to his trial—three for the prosecution, six for the defense, and several more on behalf of the court—and they conducted a battery of standard diagnostic procedures and more than 200 hours of clinical interviews All six defense experts concluded that Chapman was psychotic; five diagnosed paranoid schizophrenia, while the sixth felt that his symptoms were more consistent with manic depression The three prosecution experts declared that his delusions fell short of psychosis and instead diagnosed various personality disorders The court-appointed experts concurred with the prosecution's examiners that he was delusional yet competent to stand trial In the examinations, Chapman was more cooperative with the prosecution's mental health experts than with those for the defense; one psychiatrist conjectured that he did not wish to be considered "crazy" and was persuaded that the defense experts declared him insane only because they were hired to do so [1]


Guilty plea
Chapman's court-appointed lawyer, Herbert Adlerberg, withdrew from the case amid threats of lynching Police feared that Lennon fans might storm the hospital, so they transferred Chapman to Rikers Island for his personal safety [36]


Sentencing hearing
The sentencing hearing took place on August 24, 1981, in a crowded courtroom Two experts gave evidence on Chapman's behalf Judge Edwards interrupted Dorothy Lewis, a research psychiatrist who was relatively inexperienced in the courtroom, indicating that the purpose of the hearing was to determine the sentence and there was no question of Chapman's criminal responsibility Lewis had maintained that Chapman's decision to change his plea did not appear reasonable or explicable, and she implied that the judge did not want to allow an independent competency assessment [41] The district attorney argued that Chapman committed the murder as an easy venture to acquire fame Chapman was asked if he had anything to say, and he rose and read a passage from The Catcher in the Rye in which Holden tells his little sister Phoebe what he wants to do with his life:


Imprisonment
In 1981, Chapman was imprisoned at Attica Correctional Facility outside of Buffalo, New York He fasted for twenty-six days in February 1982, so the New York State Supreme Court authorized the state to force-feed him Central New York Psychiatric Center director Martin Von Holden said that Chapman refused to eat with other inmates but agreed to take liquid nutrients [43] He was held in a solitary confinement unit for violent and at-risk prisoners, in part due to concern that he might be harmed by Lennon's fans in the general population There were 105 inmates in the facility who were "not considered a threat to him," according to the New York State Department of Correctional Services He had his own cell but spent "most of his day outside his cell working on housekeeping and in the library." [44]


Book, interviews, and media appearances
Chapman declined all offers for interviews following the murder and during his first six years at Attica, later stating that he did not want to give the impression that he killed Lennon as a route to acquire fame and notoriety [32] Despite his claim that he refused all interviews during those six years, James R Gaines interviewed him and wrote a three-part, 18,000-word People magazine series starting in 1981 and climaxing in February and March 1987 [1] [49] [50] Chapman subsequently told the parole board that he regretted the interview [45] He gave a series of audio-taped interviews to Jack Jones of the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle, and Jones published Let Me Take You Down: Inside the Mind of Mark David Chapman, the Man Who Killed John Lennon in 1992 [51] Jones asked Chapman to tell his story for Mugshots, a CourtTV program in 2000, with his first parole hearing approaching Chapman refused to go on camera but consented to tell his story in a series of audiotapes [45]


Parole applications, campaigns, and denials
Chapman first became eligible for parole in 2000 after serving twenty years in prison Under New York state law, he is required to have a parole hearing every two years from that year onward Since that time, a two- or three-member board has denied Chapman parole thirteen times Before his first parole hearing, Yoko Ono sent a letter to the board requesting that Chapman should stay behind bars and serve out the remainder of his life sentence [54] [55] In addition, New York State Senator Michael Nozzolio, chairman of the Senate Crime Victims, Crime and Correction Committee, wrote to Parole Board Chairman Brion Travis saying: "It is the responsibility of the New York State Parole Board to ensure that public safety is protected from the release of dangerous criminals like Mark David Chapman." [56]


Timeline
Two biographical films center on Chapman and the murder: The Killing of John Lennon (2006), directed by Andrew Piddington and starring Jonas Ball as Chapman and Chapter 27 (2007), directed by J P Schaefer and starring Jared Leto as Chapman.


In film
Two biographical films center on Chapman and the murder: The Killing of John Lennon (2006), directed by Andrew Piddington and starring Jonas Ball as Chapman and Chapter 27 (2007), directed by J P Schaefer and starring Jared Leto as Chapman.


In music
Julian Cope released the song "Don't Call Me Mark Chapman" on his 1994 album Autogeddon.


See also


References


Works cited


Further reading


External links

title: Sahith_Theegala
content:
Early life
Theegala was born in 1997 in Orange, California, to Muralidhar and Karuna Theegala and has a younger brother [4] He is of Indian descent and was raised in nearby Chino Hills, California; his family came to the United States, from Telangana, India, in the late-1980s [5]


Amateur career
Theegala was a three-time NCAA All-American at Pepperdine University [1] [6] In his final year at Pepperdine, Theegala won the Southwestern Invitational, [3] the Alister MacKenzie Invitational, and the Australian Master of the Amateurs [7] His collegiate career was cut short by the COVID-19 pandemic, which forced the 2020 season to end early, with his Pepperdine team ranked first in the nation [8]


Professional career
Theegala made his professional debut in June 2020 at the Outlaw Tour's Lone Tree Classic, where he tied for third place [6] He finished T-14 at the 2020 Safeway Open on the PGA Tour He finished T-19 at his first Korn Ferry Tour event, the 2021 Chitimacha Louisiana Open He finished T-9 at MGM Resorts Championship at Paiute.


Personal life
Theegala appeared in the sports documentary series Full Swing, which premiered on Netflix on February 15, 2023 [15]

article:
Sahith Theegala

Sahith Theegala is an American professional golfer of Indian descent. Born in 1997 in Orange, California, to Muralidhar and Karuna Theegala, he has a younger brother. Theegala's family immigrated to the United States from Telangana, India, in the late-1980s.

**Early Life**

Theegala was born and raised in the United States, specifically in the nearby city of Chino Hills, California. His family's roots in India have had a significant influence on his life and career. Theegala's parents instilled in him a strong work ethic and a passion for golf, which has been a driving force behind his success.

Growing up in a close-knit community, Theegala was exposed to various sports and activities from a young age. He discovered his love for golf at the age of 8 and quickly became dedicated to the sport. Theegala's natural talent and dedication earned him recognition and accolades in his amateur career, paving the way for his transition to professional golf.

**Amateur Career**

Theegala's amateur career was marked by numerous achievements and accolades. He was a three-time NCAA All-American at Pepperdine University, a prestigious institution known for its strong golf program. Theegala's collegiate career was cut short by the COVID-19 pandemic, which forced the 2020 season to end early. Despite this setback, his Pepperdine team managed to finish the season ranked first in the nation.

During his time at Pepperdine, Theegala won several notable tournaments, including the Southwestern Invitational, the Alister MacKenzie Invitational, and the Australian Master of the Amateurs. These victories showcased his skills and talent, making him a strong contender for professional golf.

**Professional Career**

Theegala made his professional debut in June 2020 at the Outlaw Tour's Lone Tree Classic, where he tied for third place. He then competed in the 2020 Safeway Open on the PGA Tour, finishing T-14. This marked the beginning of his professional career, and he continued to compete in various tournaments, including the Korn Ferry Tour and the PGA Tour.

In 2021, Theegala competed in the Chitimacha Louisiana Open, finishing T-19 in his first Korn Ferry Tour event. He then went on to finish T-9 at the MGM Resorts Championship at Paiute, showcasing his growth and improvement as a professional golfer.

**Personal Life**

Theegala has been featured in the sports documentary series Full Swing, which premiered on Netflix in February 2023. The series provides an intimate look at the lives of professional golfers, including Theegala, as they navigate the challenges and triumphs of their careers.

**Amateur Wins**

* Southwestern Invitational
* Alister MacKenzie Invitational
* Australian Master of the Amateurs

* 2023 Corales Puntacana Resort & Club Championship
* 2023 Bermuda Championship

**Results in Major Championships**

* 2023 Masters Tournament: CUT
* 2023 U.S. Open: CUT

* 2023 PGA Championship: CUT

**Summary**

Theegala's professional career has been marked by steady improvement and growth. He has competed in various tournaments, including the PGA Tour and the Korn Ferry Tour, and has achieved numerous top-10 finishes.

**Results in The Players Championship**

* 2023: T-30

title: Charlie_Watts
content:
Early life
Charles Robert Watts was born at University College Hospital in Bloomsbury, London, to Charles Richard Watts, a lorry driver for the London, Midland and Scottish Railway, and wife Lillian Charlotte (née Eaves), who had been a factory worker [1] He had a sister, Linda (born 1944), [2] with whom he was close [3]


Career
After leaving art school, he worked as a graphic designer for an advertising company called Charlie Daniels Studios, [13] and also played drums occasionally with local bands in coffee shops and clubs He and Green began their musical careers together from 1958 to 1959, playing in a jazz band in Middlesex called the Jo Jones All Stars [8] Watts initially found his transition to rhythm and blues puzzling: "I went into rhythm and blues When they asked me to play, I didn't know what it was I thought it meant Charlie Parker, played slow." [8]


Jazz bands and Blues Incorporated
After leaving art school, he worked as a graphic designer for an advertising company called Charlie Daniels Studios, [13] and also played drums occasionally with local bands in coffee shops and clubs He and Green began their musical careers together from 1958 to 1959, playing in a jazz band in Middlesex called the Jo Jones All Stars [8] Watts initially found his transition to rhythm and blues puzzling: "I went into rhythm and blues When they asked me to play, I didn't know what it was I thought it meant Charlie Parker, played slow." [8]


Career with the Rolling Stones
In mid-1962, Watts first met Brian Jones, Ian "Stu" Stewart, Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, who also frequented the London rhythm and blues clubs, but it was not until January 1963 that Watts finally agreed to join the Rolling Stones [18] [19] Initially, the band could not afford to pay Watts, who had been earning a regular salary from his gigs [20] His first public appearance as a permanent member was at the Ealing Jazz Club on 2 February 1963 [21] Watts was often introduced as "The Wembley Whammer" by Jagger during live concerts [22]


Activities outside the Stones
Watts was involved in many activities outside his life as a member of the Rolling Stones In December 1964, he published a cartoon tribute to Charlie Parker titled Ode to a High Flying Bird [26] Although he made his name in rock, his personal tastes lay principally in jazz [27]


Personal life and public image
On 14 October 1964, Watts married Shirley Ann Shepherd (11 September 1938 – 16 December 2022), whom he had met before joining the Stones in 1963 [32] The couple had one daughter, Seraphina, born in March 1968, who in turn gave birth to Watts's only grandchild, a girl named Charlotte [33] Watts and Shirley were married for 57 years, until Watts's death in 2021 [34]


Touring and band relationships
Watts expressed a love–hate attitude towards touring, [39] stating in 2003 that he "loved playing with Keith  [Richards] and the band" but "wasn't interested in being a pop idol sitting there with girls screaming" [20] He left the band after every tour, once stating "I don't actually like touring", citing the time commitment and travel required [40] In 1989, the Rolling Stones were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Watts did not attend the ceremony [20]


Health
In the mid-1980s, Watts's previously moderate use of alcohol and drugs became excessive " [They were] my way of dealing with  [family problems] ..." he said "I think it was a mid-life crisis All I know is that I became totally another person around 1983 and came out of it about 1986 I nearly lost my wife and everything over my behaviour." [46]


Death and tributes
Watts died at a London hospital on 24 August 2021, at age 80, with his family around him [50] [51] Although the cause of death was never officially stated, Keith Richards mentioned in March 2022 that Watts had cancer [52]


Accolades
In 1991, The Guardian described Watts as an "heroic yet quaint archetype .. of the 'Rock Drummer', and we are unlikely to hear their like again" [84] The Guardian attributed his professional survival to not ever aspiring for stardom nor forcing himself into songwriting [84]


Drumming
In 1991, The Guardian described Watts as an "heroic yet quaint archetype .. of the 'Rock Drummer', and we are unlikely to hear their like again" [84] The Guardian attributed his professional survival to not ever aspiring for stardom nor forcing himself into songwriting [84]


Appearance
The Daily Telegraph named him one of the World's Best Dressed Men [91] In 2006, Vanity Fair elected Watts into the International Best Dressed Hall of Fame List [92]

article:
Charlie Watts

Charlie Watts was a British drummer and artist, best known as the drummer for the Rolling Stones. He was a key member of the band for over five decades and was known for his distinctive drumming style and his iconic appearance.

Early Life
Charles Robert Watts was born on June 2, 1941, at University College Hospital in Bloomsbury, London. He was the son of Charles Richard Watts, a lorry driver, and Lillian Charlotte (née Eaves), a factory worker. Watts had a close relationship with his sister, Linda, who was born in 1944.

Watts's early life was marked by a love of music and art. He attended Regent Street Polytechnic, where he studied art and began to develop his skills as a painter. However, it was not until he left art school that he began to pursue a career in music.

Career
After leaving art school, Watts worked as a graphic designer for an advertising company called Charlie Daniels Studios. He also began to play drums occasionally with local bands in coffee shops and clubs. It was during this time that he met Keith Richards and Mick Jagger, who would later become his bandmates in the Rolling Stones.

Watts's first professional gig with the Rolling Stones was in January 1963, when he replaced the band's original drummer, Carlo Little. He made his public debut with the band at the Ealing Jazz Club on February 2, 1963, and quickly became an integral part of the band's sound and style.

Jazz Bands and Blues Incorporated
Before joining the Rolling Stones, Watts was a member of several jazz bands, including the Jo Jones All Stars. He also played with a band called Blues Incorporated, which was a influential group in the development of British blues music.

Watts's experience with jazz and blues bands helped to shape his drumming style, which was characterized by its precision, subtlety, and sense of rhythm. He was a highly skilled drummer who was able to adapt to a wide range of musical styles, from rock and roll to jazz and blues.

Career with the Rolling Stones
Watts's tenure with the Rolling Stones was marked by numerous tours, albums, and hits. He was a key member of the band's sound, providing a distinctive and driving rhythm that helped to propel the band's music forward.

Watts was also known for his sense of humor and his ability to poke fun at himself. He was a beloved member of the band, and his relationships with his bandmates were close and enduring.

Activities outside the Stones
In addition to his work with the Rolling Stones, Watts was also a talented artist and painter. He was a prolific artist who created numerous paintings and drawings throughout his career.

Watts was also a devoted husband and father. He was married to Shirley Ann Shepherd from 1964 until his death in 2021, and the couple had one daughter, Seraphina, who was born in 1968.

Personal Life and Public Image
Watts's personal life was marked by a sense of humor and a love of music. He was a private person who kept a low profile, but he was also a devoted husband and father who was deeply committed to his family.

Watts's public image was that of a cool and detached individual who was not easily fazed by the pressures of fame. He was a highly respected member of the music industry, and his reputation as a drummer and artist was second to none.

Touring and Band Relationships
Watts was a touring musician who had a deep love of the road. He was a highly skilled drummer who was able to adapt to a wide range of musical styles, from rock and roll to jazz and blues.

Watts's relationships with his bandmates were close and enduring. He was a beloved member of the Rolling Stones, and his relationships with Keith Richards and Mick Jagger were particularly close.

Health
In the mid-1980s, Watts's health began to decline. He had been drinking and taking drugs for years, and his behavior became increasingly erratic. He checked into rehab in 1986 and began to address his addiction.

Watts's health problems continued to plague him throughout his life. He had numerous health scares and hospitalizations, but he remained committed to his music and his family.

Death and Tributes
Watts died on August 24, 2021, at the age of 80. He was surrounded by his family and friends, and his death was met with widespread tributes and condolences from the music industry.

Watts's legacy as a drummer and artist is immeasurable. He was a highly respected member of the music industry, and his reputation as a drummer and artist was second to none.

Accolades
Watts's contributions to the music industry were recognized with numerous accolades and awards. He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1989, and he was also awarded a CBE (Commander of the Order of the British Empire) in 2003.

Watts's drumming style was characterized by its precision, subtlety, and sense of rhythm. He was a highly skilled drummer who was able to adapt to a wide range of musical styles, from rock and roll to jazz and blues.

Appearance
Watts was known for his distinctive appearance, which was characterized by his tall, slender frame and his signature fashion sense. He was a stylish individual who was always impeccably dressed, and he was a beloved fixture on the fashion scene.

In 2006, Vanity Fair elected Watts into the International Best Dressed Hall of Fame List, and he was also named one of the World's Best Dressed Men by The Daily Telegraph.

Discography
Watts's discography with the Rolling Stones is extensive and impressive. He played on numerous albums, including "Beggars Banquet," "Let It Bleed," and " Exile on Main Street." He also played on many of the band's live albums and singles.

In addition to his work with the Rolling Stones, Watts also released several solo albums, including "Charlie Watts Meets the Chinese Philharmonic" and "Charlie Watts and the Tentet."

article:
**2022 French Open**

The 2022 French Open, also known as Roland-Garros, was a Grand Slam tennis tournament that took place at the Stade Roland-Garros in Paris, France, from May 22 to June 5, 2022.

**Introduction**

The French Open is one of the most prestigious tennis tournaments in the world, and it is considered one of the four Grand Slam events in the tennis calendar. The tournament is known for its challenging clay court surface and its rich history, with many legendary tennis players having won the title over the years.

**Singles Players**

As a Grand Slam tournament, the points for the French Open are the highest of all ATP and WTA tournaments. These points determine the world ATP and WTA rankings for men's and women's competition, respectively. In both singles and doubles, women received slightly higher point totals compared to their male counterparts at each round of the tournament, except for the first and last.

**Events**

The 2022 French Open featured a total of 128 players in the men's singles draw and 128 players in the women's singles draw. The tournament also included doubles events for both men and women, as well as mixed doubles, wheelchair events, and junior events.

**Men's Singles**

The men's singles event at the 2022 French Open was won by Rafael Nadal, who defeated Novak Djokovic in the final. This was Nadal's 14th French Open title, and it cemented his position as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.

**Women's Singles**

The women's singles event at the 2022 French Open was won by Iga Świątek, who defeated Coco Gauff in the final. This was Świątek's first Grand Slam title, and it marked a significant milestone in her young career.

**Men's Doubles**

The men's doubles event at the 2022 French Open was won by Marcel Granollers and Horacio Zeballos, who defeated the team of Ivan Dodig and Austin Krajicek in the final.

**Women's Doubles**

The women's doubles event at the 2022 French Open was won by Barbora Krejčíková and Kateřina Siniaková, who defeated the team of Coco Gauff and Jessica Pegula in the final.

**Mixed Doubles**

The mixed doubles event at the 2022 French Open was won by Ena Shibahara and Wesley Koolhof, who defeated the team of Ulrikke Eikeri and Joran Vliegen in the final.

**Wheelchair Events**

The 2022 French Open also featured wheelchair events, including wheelchair singles and doubles events for men and women. The wheelchair singles events were won by Shingo Kunieda and Diede de Groot, while the wheelchair doubles events were won by Alfie Hewett and Gordon Reid, and by Marjolein Buis and Diede de Groot.

**Junior Events**

The 2022 French Open also featured junior events, including boys' singles and doubles events, as well as girls' singles and doubles events. The boys' singles event was won by Gabriel Debru, while the girls' singles event was won by Amina Anshba.

**Men's Legends Doubles**

The men's legends doubles event at the 2022 French Open was won by Henri Leconte and Cédric Pioline, who defeated the team of Mansour Bahrami and Fabrice Santoro in the final.

**Women's Legends Doubles**

The women's legends doubles event at the 2022 French Open was won by Nathalie Tauziat and Maria Sakkari, who defeated the team of Nathalie Dechy and Sandrine Testud in the final.

**Point Distribution and Prize Money**

As a Grand Slam tournament, the points for the French Open are the highest of all ATP and WTA tournaments. These points determine the world ATP and WTA rankings for men's and women's competition, respectively. In both singles and doubles, women received slightly higher point totals compared to their male counterparts at each round of the tournament, except for the first and last.

The total prize money for the 2022 French Open was €42,711,000, with the men's singles champion receiving €2,300,000 and the women's singles champion receiving €2,300,000.

article:
**T.J. Miller**

T.J. Miller is an American comedian, actor, and writer. He has appeared in numerous films and television shows, and has also worked as a stand-up comedian and writer.

**Early Life and Education**

T.J. Miller was born on June 4, 1981, in Denver, Colorado. His parents, Leslie Miller and Kent Miller, are both from Kansas. His father was an attorney and his mother was a clinical psychologist. Miller has two siblings, a sister and a brother. He attended Graland Country Day School and graduated from Denver's East High School, where he was active in drama productions.

Miller moved to Chicago after high school and began performing improvisation and stand-up comedy. He attended Columbia College Chicago, but did not graduate. Instead, he focused on his comedy career, performing with local troupes and touring with The Second City for two years.

**Career**

After college, Miller moved to Chicago and began to perform improvisation and stand-up comedy, performing with many local troupes. He toured with The Second City for two years and honed his skills as a comedian. In 2008, he was named one of Variety's 10 Comics to Watch.

Miller's breakthrough came in 2010 when he appeared in the film "How to Train Your Dragon" as the voice of Tuffnut Thordarson. He has since appeared in numerous films, including "Deadpool," "The D Train," and "Office Christmas Party." He has also had roles in television shows such as "Silicon Valley" and "The Good Place."

**Stand-up**

Miller began his stand-up career in Chicago, performing at local comedy clubs and festivals. He has since toured the country, performing at comedy clubs and festivals, and has released several stand-up specials.

In 2011, Miller released a comedy rap concept album titled "The Extended Play E.P." The album features comedians Bo Burnham, Doug Benson, and Pete Holmes, as well as hip-hop artists Ugly Duckling and Johnny Polygon.

**Television**

Miller has appeared in numerous television shows, including "Silicon Valley," "The Good Place," and "The D Train." He has also had roles in television pilots and has written for several TV shows.

**Film**

Miller has appeared in numerous films, including:

* "How to Train Your Dragon" (2010)
* "Deadpool" (2016)
* "The D Train" (2015)
* "Office Christmas Party" (2016)
* "Ready Player One" (2018)

**Audio**

In 2011, Miller released a comedy rap concept album titled "The Extended Play E.P." The album features comedians Bo Burnham, Doug Benson, Pete Holmes, and hip-hop artists Ugly Duckling and Johnny Polygon.

**Personal Life**

Miller became engaged to his longtime girlfriend, actress and installation artist Kate Gorney, in 2014. They were married at the Denver Botanic Gardens on September 6, 2015.

**Legal Issues**

On December 9, 2016, Miller was arrested and jailed in Los Angeles for allegedly assaulting an Uber driver. He was released on his own recognizance after bail was set at $20,000. Miller reached a settlement with the driver in March 2018.

In 2017, an allegation against Miller from his time in college in 2001 resurfaced, part of the Me Too movement and Weinstein effect. An anonymous woman who attended George Washington University with Miller told The Daily Beast reporter Asawin Suebsaeng that Miller became violent with her during a sexual encounter; he allegedly choked, shook, and punched her in the mouth, all without her consent.

**Amtrak Bomb Threat Incident**

On April 9, 2018, Miller was arrested at LaGuardia Airport in Queens, New York, on federal charges related to a fake bomb threat made while aboard an Amtrak train. According to a Department of Justice press release, he placed an emergency call on March 18, 2018, and reported that a female passenger had "a bomb in her bag" while traveling on Amtrak train #2256 from Washington, D.C., toward Penn Station in New York City. After authorities evacuated passengers and searched Amtrak Train 2256, it turned out that Miller was actually on train #2258, which was also evacuated of passengers and searched.

**Filmography**

* Films:

	+ Office Christmas Party (2016)
	+ Ready Player One (2018)
* Television:
	+ Silicon Valley
	+ The Good Place
	+ The D Train
* Video Games:
	+ None

**References**

content:
Early life and education
Thomas Edward Sizemore Jr [2] was born on November 29, 1961 [3] in Detroit [4] His mother, Judith (née Schannault), was a member of the city of Detroit ombudsman staff and his father, Thomas Edward Sizemore Sr., was a lawyer and philosophy professor [4] Thomas Jr grew up as a Catholic and his parents divorced when he was a teenager [5] Thomas Sizemore Jr said that his maternal grandfather was of French and Native American ancestry and also that his grandfather was African-American [6] [7] He graduated from Wayne State University near downtown Detroit in 1983; he earned a bachelor's degree in theater there He received a master's degree from Temple University in Philadelphia in 1986 [2]


Career
One of Sizemore's earliest film roles was in Oliver Stone's Born on the Fourth of July (1989) [8] His other early appearances included Lock Up (1989), Harley Davidson and the Marlboro Man (1991), Point Break (1991), Passenger 57 (1992), True Romance (1993), Striking Distance (1993), Natural Born Killers (1994), and Strange Days (1995) [9] [4] [10] He had a recurring role on the television series China Beach (1988–1991) as an enlisted man named Vinnie who was in love with Dana Delany's character [11] [12] For his performance in Heart and Souls (1993), he was nominated for the Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actor [8] [13] He starred in the independent drama film Love Is Like That (1993) with actress and model Pamela Gidley and had a supporting role in Kevin Costner's Wyatt Earp (1994) as Bat Masterson [4] [14]


Music
Sizemore fronted the Hollywood rock band Day 8 [42] Formed in 2002, the band recorded a four-song EP produced and recorded by Bradley Dujmovic and former Snot/Soulfly guitarist Mike Doling Originally called "The Bystanders", the group included guitarist and co-writer Rod Castro, Alan Muffterson, Tyrone Tomke, and Michael Taylor [43]


Personal life
Sizemore married actress Maeve Quinlan in 1996 They divorced in 1999 because of Sizemore's drug problems [25] He dated Heidi Fleiss, known as the onetime "Hollywood Madam" [44] In July 2005, he became a father when Janelle McIntire gave birth to twin sons, Jagger and Jayden [45] McIntire and Sizemore ended their relationship [46]


Substance abuse and legal issues
Sizemore said that he battled drug addiction from age 15 [49] [better source needed]


Death
On February 18, 2023, Sizemore suffered a brain aneurysm at his Los Angeles home and was hospitalized at Providence Saint Joseph Medical Center in critical condition [67] [68] [69] On February 27, his representative issued a statement indicating that doctors had determined there was "no further hope" for Sizemore to recover and had "recommended end-of-life decisions" to his family [70] [71] [72] Sizemore died on March 3, 2023, at the age of 61 [69]

article:
Tom Sizemore

Tom Sizemore was an American actor, known for his versatile performances in a wide range of film genres. He appeared in over 130 films and television shows, and was a prominent figure in the Hollywood entertainment industry for over three decades.

# Early Life and Education

Thomas Edward Sizemore Jr was born on November 29, 1961 in Detroit, Michigan. His mother, Judith (née Schannault), was a member of the city of Detroit ombudsman staff and his father, Thomas Edward Sizemore Sr, was a lawyer and philosophy professor. Sizemore grew up as a Catholic, and his parents divorced when he was a teenager. He stated that his maternal grandfather was of French and Native American ancestry, and also that his grandfather was African-American.

Sizemore graduated from Wayne State University near downtown Detroit in 1983, earning a bachelor's degree in theater. He later received a master's degree from Temple University in Philadelphia in 1986. His educational background provided him with a solid foundation in the performing arts, and he honed his skills as an actor through various stage and screen roles.

# Career

Sizemore's early film roles included Oliver Stone's Born on the Fourth of July (1989) and Lock Up (1989). He continued to appear in a string of films throughout the 1990s, including Harley Davidson and the Marlboro Man (1991), Point Break (1991), Passenger 57 (1992), True Romance (1993), Striking Distance (1993), Natural Born Killers (1994), and Strange Days (1995). His performances in these films showcased his versatility as an actor and his ability to adapt to various roles.

Sizemore also had a recurring role on the television series China Beach (1988-1991) as an enlisted man named Vinnie who was in love with Dana Delany's character. His performance in Heart and Souls (1993) earned him a nomination for the Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actor. He starred in the independent drama film Love Is Like That (1993) with actress and model Pamela Gidley, and had a supporting role in Kevin Costner's Wyatt Earp (1994) as Bat Masterson.

Throughout his career, Sizemore worked with some of the most renowned directors in the industry, including Oliver Stone, John Woo, and Quentin Tarantino. He appeared in a wide range of film genres, from action and drama to comedy and horror. His performances were often marked by his intense energy and his ability to bring depth and complexity to his characters.

# Music

In addition to his acting career, Sizemore was also a musician. He fronted the Hollywood rock band Day 8, which was formed in 2002. The band recorded a four-song EP produced and recorded by Bradley Dujmovic and former Snot/Soulfly guitarist Mike Doling. The group included guitarist and co-writer Rod Castro, Alan Muffterson, Tyrone Tomke, and Michael Taylor.

Sizemore's music career was marked by his passion for rock music and his desire to express himself creatively through music. He saw music as a way to connect with his fans and to showcase his talents in a different way. While his music career was not as prominent as his acting career, it was an important part of his overall creative expression.

# Personal Life

Sizemore married actress Maeve Quinlan in 1996, but the couple divorced in 1999 due to Sizemore's struggles with drug addiction. He later dated Heidi Fleiss, known as the onetime "Hollywood Madam." Sizemore became a father in 2005, when Janelle McIntire gave birth to twin sons, Jagger and Jayden. However, he and McIntire eventually ended their relationship.

Throughout his personal life, Sizemore struggled with addiction and had a history of substance abuse. He stated that he battled drug addiction from a young age, and his struggles with addiction often affected his relationships and his overall well-being.

# Substance Abuse and Legal Issues

Sizemore's struggles with addiction were well-documented throughout his career. He stated that he battled drug addiction from a young age, and his struggles with addiction often affected his relationships and his overall well-being. His addiction issues led to a number of legal problems, including run-ins with the law and publicized incidents of substance abuse.

Despite his struggles with addiction, Sizemore was open about his experiences and used his platform to raise awareness about the dangers of substance abuse. He hoped that his candor would help others who were struggling with addiction, and provide a message of hope and recovery.

# Death

On February 18, 2023, Sizemore suffered a brain aneurysm at his Los Angeles home and was hospitalized at Providence Saint Joseph Medical Center in critical condition. On February 27, his representative issued a statement indicating that doctors had determined there was "no further hope" for Sizemore to recover and had "recommended end-of-life decisions" to his family. Sizemore died on March 3, 2023, at the age of 61.

Sizemore's death was met with an outpouring of tributes and condolences from his fans, colleagues, and fellow actors. His legacy as a talented and versatile actor will be remembered for years to come, and his contributions to the entertainment industry will continue to inspire generations of actors and filmmakers.

# Filmography

Sizemore appeared in over 130 films and television shows throughout his career. Some of his notable film roles include:

On February 18, 2023, Sizemore suffered a brain aneurysm at his Los Angeles home and was hospitalized at Providence Saint Joseph Medical Center in critical condition [67] [68] [69] On February 27, his representative issued a statement indicating that doctors had determined there was "no further hope" for Sizemore to recover and had "recommended end-of-life decisions" to his family [70] [71] [72] Sizemore died on March 3, 2023, at the age of 61 [69]

article:
The Masked Singer (American Season 6)

The Masked Singer is an American singing competition television series where contestants, known as "maskers," compete against each other while wearing elaborate costumes and masks to conceal their identities. The show is based on the South Korean format of the same name and has gained popularity worldwide for its unique blend of music, mystery, and entertainment.

The show's sixth season premiered on September 22, 2021, on Fox, with a two-night premiere event. The season features two groups, Group A and Group B, with contestants competing to win the coveted Golden Mask trophy.

Panelists and Host

The season's panelists and host returned for another season, with Nick Cannon serving as the host and Robin Thicke, Jenny McCarthy Wahlberg, Ken Jeong, and Nicole Scherzinger joining him as panelists. The panelists also competed for the Golden Ear award, with Nicole Scherzinger winning for the first time in the season.

Production

The show's sixth season was announced on May 17, 2021, prior to the airing of the fifth season's finale on May 26. The season's premiere date was confirmed on July 26, 2021, with a two-night premiere event scheduled for September 22 and 23.

Contestants

The season features a diverse range of contestants, with a combined total of 85 Grammy nominations, 27 Grammy wins, 12 Emmy nominations, 12 Razzie Award nominations, three Academy Award nominations, two Super Bowl appearances, and two lifetime achievement awards. The contestants are divided into two groups, Group A and Group B, and compete against each other throughout the season.

For the first time in the show's history, the winner of each group will face off against each other in the season finale episode. Wild cards, a concept introduced in the previous season, also return, being added to each group throughout the season to compete for the Golden Mask trophy themselves.

Episodes

The season premiered on September 22 and 23 with a two-night premiere event. Each episode features a guest panelist performance, with Leslie Jordan performing "This Little Light of Mine" as "Soft Serve" in the season's first five episodes.
